reviewText:
Okay, where to start. I figured that there was no need for me to review this game as it is so successful, but, as always, All the Steam reviews on the front of the store page are one to two sentenced jokes instead of something actually helpful. Please thumbs-up this, if you like this review, for visibility.

The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is the sequel to the critically acclaimed The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind. Knowledge of prior storylines are not needed to enjoy Oblivion, though a working understanding of TES world lore will always enhance your experience in any of The Elder Scrolls games. A good idea is to just read some of the in-game books, from time to time, as you play the game. Some of the fictional books are amazing little detours from the game world. Oblivion and Morrowind are less fantasy experience and more-so a virtual world that you live in. With mods, this experience feels more real to me than some of the Dungeons and Dragons campaigns I've played. It's incredibly easy to get immersed into this work.

Oblivion's main story leaves some to be desired. You are a prisoner who meets the Emperor (voiced by Patrick Stewart) and his guards as he flees a rumored assassination attempt through hidden tunnels in the Imperial City prison. Suffice it to say, that its' not really a spoiler that you witness the Emperor's assassination. Before the Emperor's death, he tells you that you are fated by the gods to save the Empire and close shut the jaws of Oblivion". Long story short
date: you flee the tunnels and are sent to track down the Emperor's last remaining illegitimate heir (voiced by Sean Bean) as well as pretty much single-handedly repel the invasion of Daedra from Mehrunes Dagon’s hellish plane of Oblivion.\n\nHowever
hoursPlayed: the main quest isn’t even the largest part of the game. The entire Imperial province of Cyrodiil is open to you for exploration. There are many guilds to join

And a few mods have been so well rated that they’ve become known as unofficial expansion packs.\n\nOblivion is an astounding RPG that will draw you in and stick with you for a long

reviewerDisplayName: I am just an oooold man
reviewText:
I made a Khajit and he could punch stuff. I leveled up punching stuff, running places, and jumping to their maximum level but when I went to the arena I had trouble. I easily defeated my opponents by punching them until they could no longer stand up, then continuing to punch them as they lay bloody on the arena's dirt floor. I heard the crowd roaring as my fists crashed into the Grey Orc's skull; I felt their love wash over me like a crimson silk gown. Slowly, after the vampire scum gave out his last breath, I walked out of the arena. Not in triumph, not in victory, but in remorse. I had just punched my way through a dozen or more skulls, and for what? In my agony I gloomily set up at the The Bloated Float Inn, located in the Imperial City's Waterfront District. I woke up to the sounds of rustling, was confronted by a clearly beligerant bandit. The man had no idea I was the Arena Champion, he had not heard how I crushed the skulls of countless enemies with my punching, how I jumped clear over them with little effort, or even how I ran circles around the arena dodging every single attack thrown at me before pummeling my opponents into submission. The very idea of the man standing before me, a person unknowing of my athletic prowess, set me in to an uncontrollable rage. I don't recall what happened over then next ten minutes, but my memory picks back up again standing inside of the Inn owner's cabin covered head to toe in blood. I navigated back through the ship, which now more resembled a slaughter house, to try to find someone who could tell me what happened. Located in the messhall I found a naked shivering woman named Selene. I will never forget the look on her face when I approached her, a visage of fear so vivid the viewer can feel it.

It was then I realized what event must had befallen the denizens of The Bloated Float Inn. The ingorance of that would-be bandit set me into a blood fueled rage. I slaughtered every person aboard the ship for his sin, that is, every person save for this trembling woman. I decided then and there to never use my fists again, I set off from the boat, WHICH HADN'T LEFT THE HARBOR, to embark on a pilgrimage. One that would encapsulate all nine divine shrines and eventually lead an unwilling khajit boxer to defeat the ancient Aylied king Umaril using only Talk good skill, run fast skill, and jump high skill. After defeating such an awesome foe I came to the conclusion that one need not fight with his fists to attain his goals. Through the use of hecka convincing words, speedy feet, and super strong legs, anyone can stamp out evil without ever lifting a finger.

Oblivion taught me the greatest lesson of all, that fighting is evil.

reviewText:
While people complain that the Elder Scroll games can be quite bland and you play an expressionless psychopath mass murdering your way to the top of society, Oblivion is a sterling example of one of my favourite things about PC gaming - mods.   I have hundreds from total conversions to one that adds little street cats that wander around looking cute.  Oblivion really captures the DIY aspect of PC gaming I love in a shiny giant studio package, allowing me to change almost anything i don't like about vanilla.  Unlike console people, to merely review and make judgements based on vanilla is to miss the beauty of PC gaming.  It's that kind of community that keeps an aging game fresh interesting and addictive.

As far as the extras in the GOTY go, whether you care about player houses shapes much of  the DLC, Mehrune's Razor quest is a large dungeon, nothing mind blowing if you play with Lost Spires mod, but some very shiny loot.  The Knights of the Nine was a fairly straight-forward quest, would call it a good DLC rather than an expansion pack as such.  However although you have to seriously stab someone at the end, at least some of the quests have variety in what you have to do a bit.

However Shivering Isles makes this edition worth your money imo.  It adds some much needed oddness to the game, the kind of thing where you pause to think 'wtf is that?' as some creature shuffles or leaps towards you.  Without getting into the whole 'which elder scrolls is best', one thing i felt was Oblivion and Skyrim settled with standard pseudo-medieval europe fantasy world, whereas Morrowind felt quite alien, but with it's own culture to be read about and discovered.  Shivering Isles brings that to Oblivion.  The books are a delight, and it's nice to experience a daedric realm aside from the Deadlands (which while fun, never felt like a place people lived).  All in all and bearing in mind what i said about the still quite vital mod community, I totally recommend you buy this game.

reviewText:
So, I bought Skyrim during a sale, played it the rest of the week, loved it. After much more hours, wanted to check out Oblivion, because I couln't get enough of the great series. I have 10 reasons for buying this piece of art:

1/10: Get jumpscared by kahjiit who was hiding in a bush

2/10: Disarm a deadra while having a sword duel and watch him run downhill chasing his fallen mace

3/10: (almost) no racist people

4/10: You can wield a sword and shield and heal yourself with a spell without the need of switching

5/10: The game counts the amount of jokes you have made

6/10: Epic battles in the sky above a giant wheel (the imperial city)

7/10: You can actually place objects in your house wich you can move somewhat normal, and they don't teleport back when you leave

8/10: Freedom as a mage to spell your own way (well except for some arts then)

9/10: Get jumpscared by a village of invisible people

10/10: THE. GUARDS. ARE. NOT. COMPLETE. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥S.

Anyway, if you loved Skyrim, you will love Oblivion, and probably even more. The slightly older graphics might be a setback for some, but after a while you feel perfectly comfortable with them. Just let your wallet fly to your pc and dive into hours of dungeons, cities, sigil keeps and joke-telling.

reviewText:
I've noticed that the reviews for Morrowind, Oblivion, and Skyrim tend to be about why that game is the best Elder Scrolls game and the others are terrible in comparison. I really enjoy all three of them (sorry, Arena and Daggerfall, you're just not very enjoyable by today's standards), so I figured I'll give reviews for each that focus on what's unique about each of them, and what kind of players that will appeal to.

Oblivion was my first Elder Scrolls game (and my first open-world RPG in general), so it has a special place in my heart. Anytime I hear that music come up when I launch the game, it brings back all sorts of emotions and wonderful feelings related to discovering a whole new type of game that I thoroughly enjoy. As good as the music in Morrowind was, Oblivion's music is even better for me (both are better than Skyrim's).

For positives, let's start with Oblivion being the most deliberate of the three games. What I mean by that is that things are the most contained and orderly in Oblivion. You don't accidentally" do anything in this game
date: as opposed to Morrowind and even Skyrim to a degree. Leveling up is slower in Oblivion
recommended: and so you don't race through anything. It gives you plenty of time to savor everything. You don't start a new game and find yourself pimped out with super powerful gear or spells a couple hours later. The landscape is also fairly contained

Bam. You're a prisoner. Then what? Oh, its just PICARD TELLING YOU YOU'RE IN HIS DREAMS. SECRET. PASSAGE. HE DIES (OH NOES) TAKE THIS SEXY AMULET. GET OUT OF THE SEWERS. EXPLORE FOR 100+ HOURS.

Well, you can already tell this game will be incredible.

But seriously, this game starts off very strong. You're a prisoner, with your crimes unknown to you. As long as you don't abuse the character creator (hehe...) you'll be able to mold your ideal elf, human, or orc... or cat... or lizard. But yes, many great awesome things happen in the first few minutes within the game. You may think the game is linear... until you exit that sewer.

Can I go anywhere?" "Can I follow this road?" "I want that horse. Can I steal it?" The answer to all this is a glorious "yes". Oblivion is at it's best when you're wondering along the vast land of Cyrodiil

reviewText:
What can I say about Oblivion. I was gifted the game when it came out on the Xbox 360. And after that, I continued to play it till I gave the game to my girlfriend 6 years later and bought the GOTY version on PC, which I'm playing at this moment. I have a lot more hours on PC Skyrim simply because I thought it would be better.  I was wrong. I'm now adding to my collection of inhuman hours of Xbox 360 Oblivion.
Don't get me wrong, dear Skyrim fanboy. It IS a great game, with amazing atmosphere and graphics. It one-ups Oblivion on graphics, since it's 4 years younger. But when it comes to atmosphere, Skyrim might as well be a cardboard box. Here's why:
Oblivion's soundtrack is rich and beautiful, unlike Skyrim's flat Dovahkiin" "Badass" default track every time you get in a battle.
Skyrim's main questline is almost nessisary

reviewText:
Oblivion, in my opinion, is the best game of all time. It gets a bad reputation among fans of other elder scrolls games, you see the argument that Morrowind is the game for patient players that can enjoy an older game, and skyrim is this big new awesome RPG, and so Oblivion is seen as some weird spot in the middle of the two. Yet I repeat, oblivion is the best game I have ever played.
Many Morrowind players dislike Oblivion with the argument that it is less inclusive and immersive than Morrowind. But then why is Skyrim the only game on par with Morrowind? Skyrim, the game with less weapon types, the game with the worst alchemy, the game with the worst magic? Skyrim's graphics barely surpass the incredibly captured beauty of Cyrodil, and they had five years to make skyrim. They had four to make Oblivion, and your blind grandma could easily tell the difference between that and Morrowind graphically. The gameplay was also a complete overhaul from morrowind to oblivion. People talk about how Morrowind's or Skyrim's fighting systems are so much better, with Morrowind's realistic feel that you have to be good with the weapon type or you will be awful, or with skyrim's realistic feeling combat but Oblivion completely build anew the combat system of morrowind, made it insanely more realistic, and remains the only game in the series that you can have a sword, shield, and spell at the same time.
From Morrowind to skyrim each game got easier. Morrowind is the most difficult of the three, with no quest markers on a compass, and no advice or help whatsoever. But when I went to play skyrim it was the easiest thing in the world. Anyone can take a nord with a battleaxe and beat the game. Oblivion is in the middle. Oblivion isn't like the insane difficulty of morrowind, showing how hard each quest would be were you actually to do it in real life and record the words that someone said to find a secret location. Oblivion helps you, but is not easy. The game has an easier start, but if you can remain powerful past level 30, that's when you know you're good. Skyrim is just always easy. Progress through oblivion is kind of like progress through life. The lower your level, the less you have to worry. But as you grow into the game it takes constant effort and maintenance to remain successful. In oblivion you have to have a gameplan. Will you be a thief that goes around and gets rich to make sure they have the best equipment in the game, and talks your way out of hard situations? Will you be the the brute warrior that relies on lots of stamina and power to take down less physically gifted enemies? Or will you be my personal favorite, the mage that can go about every situation in a million different ways? Sure, you can mesh these things to any degree, but the point is that if you don't go about it correctly with skills that make sense together or you use the wrong race, you won't be successful later on.
You could go on forever about the systems in place in oblivion that make it unique and amazing but Oblivion is the game that revolutionizes combat and especially graphics (Oblivion had some of the best graphics the world had ever seen, and was made on such a large scale that's almost an unimaginable feat) but sticks true to the elder scrolls mentality. Skyrim is a game to pull people into the franchise. Skyrim is the start of a new generation, a worse generation, of TES players. Oblivion is the peak in the series.

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a massive open world game developed by Bethesda and released March 20, 2006. It would take too long to list all the various quests, armor, weapons, enchantments, and magic spells you can learn/create, simply trust me when I say this game is an adventure waiting to happen.

-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: This is probably one of my personal favorite parts of Elder Scrolls of Oblivion, once you get out of the starting area you can make your own story, or follow the main story, or go search for your own quest. If you wanted, you could become a villain, you could also become a hero. The choices are completely up to you.
The whole Elder Scrolls series is very rich is lore and diversity of environment, you can read in-game books and learn useful facts about the monsters you fight. Not everyone will do this, but I ended up learning what all Trolls are weak against, and I've been using it in all Elder Scrolls games since.
I won't say much more about the story, because most of the fun is in finding the quests and stories yourself, and of course forging your own tale.... however there is one additional thing to note, in the Game of the Year Edition you get the Shivering Isles Expansion, and there you meet my favorite character in the whole series.

Game Play: You can control the camera to play in third person, or first person. (personally I always thought third person looked silly... the knee's bend funny, and when you jump your legs stay straight. seems like an indication of play in first person").
You could be a necromancer and summon skeleton hoards
date: you could be a thief and sneak into combat
recommended: you could be a warrior and smash your enemies faces in
hoursPlayed: you can be a mage and even create your own skills
voteText: you can be a ranger and pew pew

votesHelpful: an acrobat or any hybrid combination of what I've said and much much more.\n\nAchievements: There are no Steam Achievements in this game
votesTotal: you can certainly find plenty of challenges online to test your skill in the game
votesFunny: or simply increase the difficulty of the game.\n\nPrice The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Game of the Year Edition is priced at $19.99

reviewText:
My favorite game of all time!!!

I remember going over to my friends house when I was a young man and he had this game called Oblivion on his xbox. I didn't know anything of the game but one day we decided to start it up. Choosing my race and fine tuning my character was something new to me and blew me away. Then the game continued with the dark elf mocking me from my prison cell.

At that moment I was hooked and bought it for myself the next day for Xbox and then a year later for pc. It was the first game I modded and I closed every gate and explored every crevice of the map. I have spend thousands of hours on this game on the non steam edition and will play this game off and on until the day I die. I am a die hard fan of this edition into the series and no other game has ever lived up to this.

You exit the sewers and the whole world is open to you, it is your destiny and you can play how you want. All enemies scale to you so you can go anywhere on the map. North east south west it does not matter forge your own journey the game allows you to role play to the max being who you want to be.

My all time favorite game gets an 11/10 and will always be the best game in the series in my heart and I hope you can get the same expirenced as I have.

reviewText:
Overview
The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is the fourth installment of the series and one of the most known and loved fantasy RPG in gaming. Released in 2006 by Bethesda, the game is still very played to this day, and has a very active modding community, which is a testament of the life-span of a great game. Embark on a journey full of lore, quests and dungeon explorations in this masterpiece of a game.

The ProsEnticing Gameplay - Oblivion is a game that really nails it when it comes to gameplay. You always find some new quest to do or a new dungeon to explore, people to gossip, barter or fight with. The large, open map provides many opportunities to explore and create your own adventure. Even if you already completed the game and know the majority of quests, it’s still fun to replay them. The quests are very well done, and much more diverse than one might expect, primarily due to the rich backstory they provide.

Long Completion Time - Don’t worry about running out of things to do. There are over 200 quests and 400 locations to discover, explore and loot. Not to mention this is a Role-Playing Game. You can have multiple playthroughs, each with it’s own different approach on what and who you are, how you attack, and how you respond at moral decisions in quests.

Beautiful Soundtrack - This game has, in my opinion, the best soundtrack in the history of gaming. The music is very well made for each situation. It is relaxing when wandering, thrilling when in battle. Jeremy Soule really hit the nail on its head on this one.

Modding - Head on over to Oblivion Nexus to download and install a few of thousands of available mods, that fix most if not all problems vanilla oblivion has. Bug fixes, texture enhancements, ENBs, UI redesigns, quest mods, item mods, gameplay tweaks, and so much more are being offered by the modding community. This is one of Oblivions strongest points, and will definitely make the game several times more enjoyable. Just make sure you take your time to research, download and organise them before you start playing.

Expansion Packs - We all know the famous “Horse Armor” DLC fiasco, but let’s not get in the way of its actual expansion packs, namely Knights of the Nine and The Shivering Isles. The latter is considered one of the best expansion packs that were ever released, and comes included in the Game of the Year version on Steam. It adds lots of new content, including maps, items, quests, characters and  gameplay elements.
The ConsVanilla Version - This is just informing you that the vanilla game you get when you first download it is a bit underselling. The graphics are outdated(Duh! 2006 game) and there are quite a few (hundred) small bugs and other inconsistencies that may occur during gameplay, the faces of characters look… well, hideously ugly in some cases. All of these problems and many more are easily fixed with a few tweaks and mods and you can enjoy a better, prettier, and more stable version by installing them. There are loads of bits and pieces I could write long rants about, but there’s a mod for all of them, so I won’t bother. I will concentrate only on the things inherently bad about the game that cannot be fixed (in most cases)

Voice Casting - Given that Patrik Steward voiced about 5 minutes of emperor Uriel’s lines, the budget was already out the window, so we are left with about… a few handfuls of voice actors, each representing their race. This makes it a little weird having every member of a gender and race sound the same, with a few exceptions. Albeit, in order to do this, each actor recorded the entirety of the dialogues, even ones that would never be used by their characters, for safe-proofing. A lot of work to be admired, however the problem of little to no diversity between characters’ voices is a little disappointing. Which isn’t to say they sound awful. The sound quality is good and the actors are talented. It’s just that everything sounds the same. Also, you may encounter beggars that change voices radically between different topics.

Totalitarian Crime System - There is a running gag of the telepathic guards that roam Oblivion in search for you. Doing any murder, even in complete and utter stealth, even in the most devoid of any witnesses location, that crime will be recorded, a bounty will be placed on your head, and sometimes guards might leave the cities in search for you and they know exactly where you are. Not only this, but touching items is a crime. You are a guest in someone’s home. You see a misplaced fork on the table and just want to nudge it a bit to align it with the plate. Yup, you are going to be arrested. Or say you broke in someone’s house late at night, and you steal an apple. That apple is now known throughout the entire province of Cyrodill as being stolen and cannot be sold to anyone but thief guild fences. You can come to a merchant with 20 apples, but he will specifically know that only 18 of them are righteously yours. You can’t sell the other two. How!? Why!?

Uneven Leveling System - (fixable by mods) The world seems to be leveling with you, which seems stupid. By about level 20, every common bandit you find will be equipped with the best grade weapons and armor, which breaks the immersion and unbalances the game. Also, attaining the perfect character (max stats) requires a deep understanding of the leveling system and painstakingly much micro-management.
Conclusion
It may seem the cons list is longer, but trust me, this game is amazing. It is one of my favorite games of all time, and have been rocking a lot more hours before I got it on Steam. If you like RPGs, then this is a must have. I recommend it with all my heart. Be sure to mod it and to try to find everything there is to do in it. To help you, here are some links:

UESP Wiki[www.uesp.net] - Huge Wiki of everything you need to know.
Modding Guide - List of my favorite mods, why and how to install them.

If you enjoyed this review and want to see more of my work, consider joining my group and follow my curator page! Link to the right!Jad's List - Curator Group

reviewText: Okay,\n\nSo as a person who started off in the Elder Scrolls series at the game Skyrim, oblivion never really appealed to me. It looked so outdated, i couldnt stand the graphics, and having briefly watched people play it in the past it didnt look like it could ever compete with a game that holds such a great magnitude as Skyrim. I am happy to say that i was completely ignorant for thinking that and Skyrim will be collecting dust for a while. So my friend gifted me this and i started playing, the first few hours were like meh, not sure what to think. As i explored more of oblivion and got into the main quest and starting seeing the guilds, the mechanics in this game and the depth surpass skyrim in literally all aspects.. And ive only been playing for around 3 days now and already clocked in 20+ hours. The amound of lore, the unbelievablely deep quests and the characters that you remember. Its absolutely mesmorizing. To think of the age of this game and the fact that im just starting now, in 2016, to get into oblivion i dont even know what to say. This game is the best rpg ive ever played in my life. It keeps the player interested as i continue through the game and keep wanting to learn more and oblivion actually makes you want to learn more about the lore behind the elder scrolls. It has inspired me to eventually buy morrowind as ive become so interested in the lore behind the elder scrolls because of this game. It feels so much more authentic than skyrim. I enjoy the combat so much more. And it is so much more immersive than skyrim wil ever be. And i only have very few mods for the game. The exploration aspect of the game is so much more rewarding than skyrim's and you actually have to put in a lot of work to become even somewhat powerful. This game is a committment and makes you work your ♥♥♥ off for the things that you want. So anyone who plays the hell out of skyrim and thinks its the best RPG. I dont care what year it is, put that game down and give this one a try. You wont regret it.

Make sure you buy the GoTY DELUXE version of the game - if you don't, you'll miss out on all of the smaller DLC, as they are not sold seperately and cannot be purchased afterwards!

EDIT:
If you're looking for better graphics, check out Oblivion Reloaded @ Nexusmods, link here: http://www.nexusmods.com/oblivion/mods/45749/?

Oblivion Reloaded replaces previous versions of OBGE and overall is more power and efficient than alternatives (possibly even ENB).

So yep, the game is still being modded.

Reviewing Oblivion is a little tricky for me because I've had it for years. Many, many years. I've literally had it since sometime during good ol' 2007. Thousands of hours easily poured into the none-steam version of the game, and time I do not regret putting into the game.

It was, simply put, a centrepiece to the later years of my childhood. I enjoyed it so much I bought it on Steam too, so in case I ever lose any of the disks for whatever reason, I've got the steam version as a backup.

So beyond countless hours playing the game, I've also got another issue. Mods. One really should not review a game on the basis of what users have created out of it -- even if modding is a huge aspect of the game -- but I do have some difficulty doing so accurately doing so, so you may have to bare with me.

Gameplay:

Oblivion had unique gameplay. For someone who had never played anything like it, Oblivion was something above and beyond anything I'd ever played. To this day, Oblivion has a number of unique gameplay features that aren't present in, say, Skyrim. I'll give some big differences below.

- An attribute system. Each attribute governs a number of different skills and has a number of affects. Attributes such as Endurance, Agility, Intelligence and so on. For many players such as myself, these attributes add something extra to the game.

- Fame and Infamy system. Your actions have a limited impact on the world in terms of disposition. People will react to you differently - murder lots of people, and people will react to it in terms of their opinion of you.

- Repair skill and durability of weapons and armour - you need to manage the integrity of your equipment, or else watch it degrade and eventually break. There is even a hand-to-hand skill, so you can train yourself to kill people with your bare fists if you want to.

- Disposition system. People like you more or less depending on events, infamy/fame, quests and even the silly mini-game in the game you can use. Personality attribute also has a big impact.

- Scaling in the game is, to be blunt, terrible. At the beginning of the game, you'll find a rather friendly and not so hostile world. Deer will roam the wilds and slaughterfish will slaughter you whilst mudcrabs pick at your corpse. Skyrim does this slightly better, but mods can fix this in Oblivion.

- Birthsigns are selected at the beginning of the game and have a permanent effect. Your birthsign will have a number of effects, ranging from lesser and greater powers to minor impacts on your attributes. This initial decision may full well shape your character in ways you will not be able to change later.

- Working item moving. It's much better in Oblivion than Skyrim - you have much more control over the moving of items around your house and all that, with fewer bugs and what-not.

- Lots of different armour pieces. Greaves, Gauntlets, Chestplate, Helmet and Boots.

And much more. Actually, there is an entire page dedicated to it right here, including the differences between Morrowind too: http://www.uesp.net/wiki/Differences_Between_Morrowind,_Oblivion,_and_Skyrim

Now onto modding (my original review with minor edits).

Beyond vanilla gameplay, which intitially I thought was great, mods can turn the game into something completely different. Add in Deadly Reflex or UV to get a deadly and bloody game, despite being somewhat unrealistic. Or maybe go for Duke Patrick's combat mods and find yourself playing a realistic combat game.

Or download thousands of other mods and mix and match to create a game that is unique for you. Don't like the levelling and skill progression? No problem. Grab numerous mods that edit the system, changing it into something more casual, more hardcore or even something completely different. XP system? Gotcha.

I've played the game through multiple times over the years. I have to say, I'm still not bored of it, though I did take a break for a couple of years whilst I played Skyrim and Morrowind.

Graphics are a little bit dated. But plenty of mods around it to bring it up to Not-Quite-Skyrim quality.

tl;dr: It may follow Bethesda's formula of open-world enjoyment, but this one (and Morrowind) doesn't hold your hand.  It has enough RPG elements to make one playthrough of the game different from another.  Combat and bugs are aplenty, but the quests and varied map make up for those shortcomings.

9/10

I first played this game back when I was 13. This was the first Elder Scrolls game that I was subject to (I was slightly too young to be interested in Morrowind at the timeit was released).  I had never played a game that allowed for such open-ended exploration and freedom.  This blew my mind when I first played and it seemed like there was always something new to find out in the world.  As a kid obsessed with this new experience, much of the flaws never really surfaced.

Fast forward 10 years.  For nostalgia's sake, I take another trip down memory lane.  It isn't as fantastic as I remember it (but nothing is as good as the first time).  The exploration is still the best part of this game (as it is with all Bethesda games), but the problem is, once you've seen everything, a game can get old quick when it relies heavily on exploration.  This is the problem with all future Bethesda games (but that's a conversation for another time).  The quests are what elevate Oblivion.  There are still some fetch quests, but I think those are few and far between in this game.  If there are fetch quests, they dress them up and throw in plenty of twists to make it interesting.  The best part is there are tons of quests in this game.  Reliving those, or trying out new ways to complete them made this second playthrough incredibly enjoyable. Oh, and do yourself a favor and play through the best DLC/expansion Bethesda has ever made.  Shivering Isles was so diverse and included so much content that I feel like I still haven't done everything to do there.

Downsides: Bugs, no real controller support, potato faces.

reviewText:
There's no  way  a short review such as this   can do justice to a game like Oblivion, it's too massive and there' too much to experience, especially when you factor in the number of custom made modifications that are available for this game.  Almost approaching the same as Unreal Tournament and the early Battlefield games (BF1942, BFV and BF2); we're talking several hundred gigabytes of free content at least (I have around 500GB for Oblivion and over a Terabyte for Battlerfield 2).

The initial stage of the game where you have to escape the cobwebbed, dark and sometimes dank dungeon is   a little depressing, but still   a pleasure to experience the first few times around (it’s one of only   a few  linear parts of the game - another one is where you get transported into a painting), then you hit the outside, exiting the dungeon via a sewer drain.  On my first time it was a moonlit night and I was actually awed by the sight that I beheld.  I could see   the dark shapes of mountains and   the moonlight gave an eerie look to the small clouds slowly passing by.  The sky was full of glittering stars and I could see some distance ahead to a small broken down castle keep, all of which, even in the dark looked amazing.  I thought Morrowind was fantastic, but this was even better.

I waited utill sunrise and was even more impressed by the amazing vista before me, Mountains  clothed in forests, morning mist,   a sun rise that looked almost real and  amazing,  the lush grass waving in the breeze, and    a whole host of other things swamped my  visual cortex.  Every step of the way, I marvelled at how realistic the grass, rocks and other objects looked.  Buildings, the imperial city, villages and towns all had their own distinct feel and charm.  The transition from night to day and back to night  is a pleasure to see; with HDR lighting, bloom effects, specular highlights and  parallax mapping  giving the game    some of the best visuals I’ve seen to date (well, maybe not the last    couple of years of AAA  game releases).  The effects are amazing, even now seven years after its release it still looks brilliant.  You can get several mods that improve many of the textures (the largest of these is around 3GB in size).

The usual RPG elements are present; for example, levelling up, plus  resource collection for  crafting magical weapons and  potions as well as stocking  yourself with  better armour, weapons , arrows, spears, potions etc.    Combat is nothing special, but still satisfying when swapping between bow, sword spear and magic.  Despatching enemies isn’t too hard, especially once you’ve got a steady stream of healing potions.

If you still haven’t purchased this game, now is the time to get it.  It includes   the expansion The Shivering Isles and the mod package Knights of the Nine that contains several   new missions, etc.  You can see several videos HERE,  HERE, HERE, HERE and HERE.


The first one is  the escape from the dungeon, the next  two videos are in and around Cyrodiil  and the last two relate to the Oblivion gates.

reviewText:
The Elder Scrolls: Oblivion is by far my favourite in the series. I have played the Elder Scrolls since Morrowind came out way back and have continued it's amazing legacy in my life to this very day. Of course, it comes with bugs and glitches but what do you expect from a massive RPG such as this? Anyways, besides from the graphics and quests, my favourite part of this game has always been the modding community and also being a part of it.

My days began way back when I was 12/13 so a good 6 years ago, when I discovered mods and how awesome they were. Graphics were always an important thing in mind so mods such as Qarls Texture Pack 3 (the best one at the time and still is I believe) was an amazing thing to have. All the small mods, such as keychains, graphics, sound overhauls, OPEN CITIES etc were what made this game, and also the rest in the series truly amazing. Sure having a flying dragon or flying skyship was awesome, but it wasn't something you'd always be using and seeing.

There were still many bugs in the later releases however an Unnofficial fix was released (many times) to fix what Bethesda could and did not. This helped greatly with smooth gameplay and to fix errors.

I haven't covered nearly 5% of what I wanted to type as this game is just truly amazing and my favourite in The Elder Scrolls.

Check out PlanetElderscrolls and The Nexus for mods and make sure you know what you're doing by reading the Readme files and guides.

If you have only played Skyrim, you probably won't like Oblivion that much because everything isn't as 'immersive' graphics wise, but to us who started here, I think we can agree that the Replay Value outnumbers Skyrim's.

reviewText:
If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs
3 tablespoons sugar
3 tablespoons melted butter
40 ounces softened cream cheese
1 cup sugar
3 tablespoons flour
1 tablespoon vanilla
1 cup sour cream
4 eggs

Directions:
For The base:.
If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375.
Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on.
Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter.
For the batter:.
Make sure everything is at room temperature.
Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this.
Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition.
Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours.
Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight.
Release the sides of the springform.
Eat.

reviewText:
Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a gem within the Elder Scroll series.

What was good about Morrowind was brought over to this 4th installment of the series, and of course, what was bad. Was either taken out, or refined and polish for a much smoother experience.

This game is huge, then what the game let's on. From quests just about almost everywhere you go. With impress lore and backstory. Not to mention the various challenges in these dark and creepy dungeons. Another great thing about Oblivion is it's class system. Unlike in Skyrim where you play as you want. Here you play based on a set of class. And therefore the game experience for you could either be hard or easy, Depending upon what class you play as.

To add on the 500+ in Oblivion you got a stable (still active) modding community plus DLC quests like Knights of Nine and Shivering Isles. Which that place adds even MORE hours into Oblivion.

To add on this amazing experience is these beautiful towns and cities filled with the sam- der i mean different variety of characters each one having their own set schedule, personal opinon, and even the way they see you (through fame or infamy status) the world is very active around you within this game.

There are at least two negatives about this game, that i can point out.

1. NPC's are literally forgettable, this being the reason why Skyrim's NPCs are vastly superior than Oblivion's NPCs, and more flexiable than Morrowind's NPCs. The Oblivion character models are literally the same, except with a few minor face tweaks with the hair, nose, eye color and so on. Plus with the same voice acting it doesn't really help who is who in the world.

2. Combat is sluggish, Yes. Even though it's a class based system. It will take a while, a long while before finding the right tune for your character to even remotely survive in the combat. Really it's just: block, lung, block, fire a spell, block. Rinse and repeat. Sometimes you are on the defensive the entire time or not even bothering going through that dungeon and just drinking buffer poitions outside the dungeon. Can you say it's because of the player level..perhaps. But even then the combat is still sub-par.


If you love a cross between Morrowind and Skyrim. I highly recommend getting this game. This is the one to have in your RPG collection.

reviewText:
Fantastic game! Oblivion is one of those games that only comes from time to time, just imagine how much the developers put into this game, time, ideas , money. Thank you Bethesda! I confess it was the first game in the Elder Scrolls series I played, so I can not compare to Morrowind, and Skyrim I barely played, then I'll make a review based solely on impressions of the game.

It took a while until I get to continue on a character and finish the main quest, the game requires dedication, Cyrodill world is vast , the possibilities in a TES game well, you need to explore,  learn about, otherwise you will getting lost as I did several times and so I abandoned the progress with other characters.

The wealth of detail is impressive, the plot of the main quest not, but everything else makes up for this fact, the quests are very well written, some are so smart that I was surprised. The possibilities are endless too, this is a true Role Playing Game, you can make a character and be what you want from a killer thief going through a heroic warrior to a simple traveling merchant, or all together.

The graphics are outdated and mechanics are strange at first sight, especially the combat and movement, and the animation of NPCs give the impression that they do not have emotions. Despite this the game is still very good, the graphics can be improved with mods, you get used to the mechanics and also the sound effects are well done. The community is huge and active, there are thousands of fan-made mods that help solve problems, improve gameplay, graphics and add content that make it practically a new game.

I highly recommend it, but as said, you need to devote to it, it takes a while to get a feel and learn how the gameplay works, how the skill system and leveling for example. But there are wikis for it with everything you can know about TES: Oblivion, I recommend consulting to aid, but being careful with spoilers, of course.

9/10

reviewText:
The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is one of the greatest games I have ever played. Made in 2006, the game still continues to amaze me, to this very day! Back those days, this game was considered as one with the most realistic graphics (Even today, they are not bad). And it was a HUGE leap from it's predecessor, Morrowind, by all accounts. But, of course, it is not perfect. Nothing is.

Well, here's my pros and cons of this game:

Pros: - the main storyline
- the world's size and details
- character customization
- the guilds and their respective quests
- the spells (better than Skyrim's if you ask me)
- the ability to make your own spells (Not available in Skyrim)
- the look of the cities
- the soundtrack
- Mods, the possibilities are endless
Cons: -  the lockpicking system!
- armor and weapons can break and need repairing (OK, this is probably made to add realism, but I still find it annoying)
- too little amount of voice actors
- fast travel made it too easy (you have access to all the cities in the beginning so that really kills the exploration feeling)
- combat was a bit dull

But despite it's minor flaws I still enjoy the game. And recommend.

reviewText:
Story? Great, but morrowind's was better.
Gameplay? It has aged. I won't hide it. Skyrim really has better mechanics for basically everything, but this game is a lot simpler to pick up and has better quests and storylines.
Atmosphere? Best out of the series. Although they couldn't afford to hire more than 8-12 voice actors.
Graphics? Good for a game from 2006, but it still looks amazing on max settings. Still, graphics mods polish it.
Physics? Try decorating your house. It's painful.
Leveling up and build system? Complex, but dumbed down from Morrowind, for the better.
Game length? Doing every quest and completing every guild + all the DLC = More than likely 200+ hours. Very rich.
Better than Skyrim? Absolutely. But it has aged, and won't live up to the more modernized style of Skyrim.
Has it aged well? Not quite, but you can still play it if it doesn't crash. From what I know, some cards actuall aren't compatable with the game. Mainly AMD cards, but see what cards can run this game before you buy it. It may be 20$ thrown out the window if your card isn't compatable.

Most negative reviews are either about how it can't run on their computer or how people like it for nostalgia. Don't listen to those reviews. The game is well worth the 20$ if you are really into vintage games like this that are heavy with roleplay elements that aren't dumbed down.

reviewText: The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is an absolutely great title and is one of, if not, the best titles in the Elder Scrolls series. Oblivion was my very first introduction to the Elder Scrolls and I enjoyed the game so very much from start to finish. The sense of immersion along with the well balanced gameplay and epic storyline was quite enjoyable for a roleplaying enthusiast like me. This title is so chock full of adventure and combat that it will keep you busy for hour upon hour which will eventually compile into weeks and months before you realize it. Graphically, you have to remember that this title was released quite a few years ago, it pales in comparison to some of todays RPG's but even so I found the basic game to be quite beautiful with a uniqueness of it own that completely fits the fantasy world and story that it places you in. I said that graphically it pales in comparison to some of todays titles" but I think this game still looks as good if not better than alot of the current roleplaying games available...this title was ahead of it's time and the work that the developers put into it definitely shows. Of course

You can mod the game from the start but I as well as others agree that playing through the base untouched game the first time is a wise thing to do. This title is simply fantastic and is highly recommended!!!"

reviewText: Oblivion may not be as advanced as Skyrim, but in my opinion it's still much better. When you join a guild or faction in Oblivion, you slowly work your way up to the top. When you join a guild in Skyrim, you are super important right from the start. For example, The Dark Brotherhood in Skyrim has you as the listener right after the first couple of grunt quests. In Oblivion, you don't become the listener until the very end, after you've poured your heart and soul into completing every quest. This is just one example, all of Skyrim's guilds are like this. Oblivion makes you work for your success, its storyline is better, and the overall feel of it is much more memorable. Skyrim is a good game, Oblivion is a FANTASTIC game, 10/10 would erase my memory and play Oblivion all over again. So before you buy any other game, STOP RIGHT THERE CRIMINAL SCUM, get Oblivion GOTY Edition.

reviewText: Bethesda Softworks has made a name for itself by making games that were WAY too ambitious for their time.\nOblivion is no exception, when i escaped the first dungeon, after fighting for my life against some cult known as the Mythic Dawn, i had absolutely no idea what to do next! And the great thing is, i didn't have to do anything. Oblivion is the sort of game where you are encouraged to walk the woods picking up daisies or to go hunting deer. There are so many things to do! If you are someone who is new to the fantasy/rpg genre and eager to get your feet wet, then Oblivion is for YOU!\nEnjoy :-)

reviewText:
What is there to say about Oblivion, aside from it possibly being the last great RPG that Bethseda has made, or possibly ever get around to making. It comes from a time when Bethseda was changing markets, from PC based RPG's, to more casual easy to pick up games. It also came at a time when games were first marked with the treachery known as DLC.

It would be a lie to say that Oblivion does not suffer from this casualization to some degree, the forefront simply being that system requirements for consoles forced the devs to reduce content in a lot of areas. namely spells such as levitation or jump from Morrowind as players would be able to fly over city walls that simply had to be closed off.

It also brought along click and go fast travel. Morrowind was all about exploration, getting lost and killed was all part of the game. This lost feeling never really happened with Oblivion.

However, along the lines, Bethseda never really was sure about everything. they still had proper enchanting and spellmaking, they still had very good quests and something that Skyrim was never given. Character building.

Simply being able to set up your character made the game feel whole. Bethseda's has always been bad with supergod main characters over agent of change characters for RPG's... but in the sense of the universe, it makes sense, for who the character is.

Skyrim didn't give you the opportunity to set up your character. You could be anything. Oblivion, you could be anything as well, but at least you still had skills you were mastered in, attribute's about your person you can change. Morrowind, you better make damn sure to use the skills you started with until you had the gold to start training in them. before that, well, you better select some Magic skills if you wanna even talk to someone from the Mage's guild.

And the quests. If I said gravekeeper would you know who I was talking about?
what about this 50 gold for a set of nice silverware.
mother?
Ayleid statues?
Cheese, Yarn and lettuce?

if you don't, well, you should. if you haven't played it, you would instantly know why you remember these once you do. because, unlike future games. questing involved questing. not going into a dungeon dodging skinwalking jerky geezers who occasinally yell at you so hard you roflcopter the floor whilst saving the day from bad dragon. or another settlement needs our help.

reviewText:
Oh Oblivion, Oblivion, Oblivion you are such a ♥♥♥♥ing good game.

A perfect game in many respects.
Do yourself a favour, and admit this is bethesdas ultimate RPG, more of an RPG than Skyrim and groundbreaking in many ways.
This game is not only extremely ahead of its time, but is an instant classic. I don't think a fantasy RPG could come close to what this game can do considering it was almost 10 years ago.

Considering the original pc version, xbox 360 version offline hours on this I must have played 800 hours-1000 hours over the years. And I could still easily play this game and find something new.

From its rich world and cities that just feel.. right.. real.. to its radiant AI system and the main quest being enjoyable while being rather questionable.
This is easily one of my most favourite games ever and likely always will be.

reviewText:
I have been wanting to review this for a while on Steam. When I first picked this game up in 2007 for the Xbox 360, I fell in love with The Elder Scrolls at a level Morrowind could never install upon me.

62 hours played? That's on the Steam version. I have well over 1500 hours invested in this game. And there is STILL a bit more ccontent I haven't covered.  Mostly small things, like fetch quests and in 100% honesty I have never gotten around to finishing the Knights of the Nine DLC.

Visually, the game hasn't aged very well. Combat wise, the game is rather simplistic. Let's talk about those.

Now I usually don't take visuals too seriously, but keep in mind a game of this scope back in 2006 didn't have high requirements for visuals. A lot of people complain that the faces of most of the human races look really odd with questionable colouring, and that Orcs just look like green humans with different lips and teeth. Completely true. However, that doesn't really do much to your immersion, in the long run. The enviroments are huge, the number of running proceses overturns the 300 mark, and in 2006 you couldn''t have good graphics, a huge world AND good performance all at the same times as loading areas smoothly and quickly with no FPS drops. For what it has to work with, the visuals at the time were very good. Well done, lads.

Segmenting towards gameplay, let's talk about the combat. If you have played Morrowind, it will feel dumbed down, if you have played Skyrim it will feel rigid and overly fast-paced. The combat AI is pretty bad. I'll give you a rundown of every enemy's AI:

Melee Weapon equipped, no Shield.:
If the enemy is visible, attack it. Between every 3-5 basic attacks, use one of 3 power attacks. If low on fatigue or have just used a power attack, block for a few seconds. Successful block means it's time to basic attack 2-4 times. Restart cycle. Never block if you are a monster like a zombie, troll or bear, but do block if you are a Ogre, Spider Daedra or Mountain Lion.

Melee Weapon and Shield:
If the enemy is visable, charge in. Do same formula as with no shield equipped, but block before each cycle and power attack if the opponant attacked you while blocking.

Ranged Weapon:
Fire when visable. Step aside between each shot. If enemy is close, switch to melee weapon if one is in inventory.

Magic User:
If it breathes, cast a spell at it. If it is close, use a touch spell. Use melee weapon when they are close, then back up after 1 cycle.

Yeah, not the smartest combat AI ever. If they have a low movement speed, you can literally just kite them with a longsword, spell or bow, and they will never once change tactics. Bad AI is bad. But when not in combat, they are generally interesting. They react to your crimes, reporting them to he guards or shrugging it off depending on how much they like you and what factions you belong to, and each and every civilized NPC has a full in-game month's worth of routines - shopping, sleeping, talking, running around on a horse until they get killed by highwaymen... very detailed stuff.

The rest of the gameplay is what makes up for the poor combat. Oblivion was designed as a story and world-centric RPG, rather than a combat-based one. You can spend 200 hours just shopping and decorating your house alone. Did I say house"? I meant "houses". There's 8 of them

reviewText:
Dear God This is a BEAUTIFUL GAME. The Gameplay, The Feel, The Intensity,The story,... THE WORLD.
Oblivion is a truley aspiring and wonderful addition to the great Elder Scrolls Saga. in my own opinion , Oblivion dominates over its very successful predecessors, those of which all have thier own very unique and lovable aspects and styles while still maintaining the entire feel of the series. Although I have played (with intense Love) Skyrim for many years (even after playing the entire Vanilla + the DLCs) I find my self going back to the one before, OBLIVION. when I play in this world, i feel a greater response to the environment of the game and what it offers than that of which I do in pretty much any other game. Aside from my personal view, Oblivion (for its time) had exceptional graphics and overall quality,compared to the games of our later generations, it still rocks the boat, (and seems to still be loved pretty much the same if not more than when it was in its new released years, ((when it was brand new)) .

reviewText:
It says I only have 3.5 hours on this (as of written review), but that's through launching it with steam, I've sunk at least one thousand on my old 360 back in 06-07.

I know more people are familiar with skyrim, so if you've played skyrim and want to check out oblivion, here are some things you need to know.

-Lock picking system is very different and can be much more challenging at the higher ranked locks.
-All the npc's kinda look fat and ugly. (you'll have to get used to it)
-The terrain is a lot more lush with green forests, not like skyrims winter tundra.
-Every NPC ♥♥♥♥ing hates your guts and doesn't suck your ♥♥♥♥. You're no dragonborn here, your practically a nobody until the near end of the game.
-No duel weild magic and swords.
-Dark Brotherhood, at least I think, is a lot more fleshed out with better quests.
-Modding community is not as alive as skyrim (but it's there) and oblivion doesn't have the steam workshop supporting it. You'll have to use nexus if you want to mod, although the vanilla game is tolerable.
-Voice acting I thought was a lot nicer, I can only hear that one male nord voice for so long.

There are plenty of other differences but to me both games are just as good even with their differences.
9/10

The life and times of a boy lost in Cyrodiil
So one day I was casually cliff jumping my way up the Jeral mountains, and I stumbled upon two Imperial Hunters having a casual archety competition. In an attempt to join in, the two of them started attacking eachother in a duel to the death.

reviewText:
An epic, truly epic. Of all proportion
The game will draw you in and take you into its self, it is so immersive and in my opinion the greatest of all role playing games. The feel is so geniune, so original and so magical.. it's like watching a medieval fantasty film from perhaps the seventies.. if you can imagine that and have a splendid feeling, then you must be interested.
There is no comparison to this. Absolutley not. It is far too spectacular in its glory for that. Now you must understand that this game brought me into the world of role playing games, my favored genre, for their humming realism and grand feats of imaginative speldour, I got the game of the year edition, and that disk span in my xbox for well over well, my save game had 657 or so days there. I would say around three thousand hours I have played Oblivion.

Now one who has the skill to tell a detailed tale of their adventures in life may do so wonderfully. I belive it would take me much more practice to do enough justice that would suit my liking to this game. I will only ramble on at things that come into my mind.

So for the overall aestheics... oh man. words really cannot do justice on this. It is something very very special. Now this does give me nostalgia and so I am being biasedly complementary here, I remember the smells of snack food like oranges and the smell of meat and pasta, or any other combination.. and dust.. dust gives me much nostaligia of earlier days. This goes well with the theme, a quite colourful and dainty civilisation, obvious fantasy articles and easy lovely heads up display : ). Please man, if you like, check out a video of some menial gameplay from someone else, to get a feel of what this is like
I shall get into some gameplay descritions now, (which I must say are not entirely top notch) as I say, you must be imaginitive! That is the magic touch, for me at least.. well they go so well if you add your own self to it :), so they work simply, and add no mess, like they are working real time and are a glance at the world, moving you ever further.
Now I hope I do not have to tell you what you can do! As with many other games of its kind, you can... go foraging in the forest for example, find fruits & berry leaves for example, and go to a station of which you can work to boil up potions... you can do the vast array as normal, with no taints, no faults.
I am telling you, this is a super extrodinary game. A pioneer! I suggest that you must own this game, you know there is a balance of, mountains and snow, swamp and rivers, grassy hills with nearby caves, farmland and noble cities.. creatues galore, none out of place or without a story intertwined. The serenity.
Oh my I could call this perfect. I do love it. Well that is all I shall say, for if you do not know of The Elder Scrolls then, I say get to.

reviewText:
The first time I played Oblivion, I hated it. I thought it had the worst character models of all time, and the combat took too long and felt unnecessarily difficult, I immediately developed the opinion that Skyrim was the best game in every regard. That was probably one of the biggest mistakes I've ever made concerning a video game. The thing about oblivion that makes it the polar opposite of Skyrim is that, the more you play Oblivion, the better it gets. Meanwhile Skyrim is magical at first, and then progressively gets way too easy and tedious. So heres why you need to play Oblivion in 2016:
1) The combat
As mentioned antecedently, Oblivion combat system is ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at first, but then, very similarly to Morrowind, you feel yourself getting progressively more powerful. You start as someone less dangerous than a native american toddler with cerebral palsy, but turn into one of the most epic warriors on the face of Tamriel. It also requires more skill, you need to strafe and blocking actually consistently makes a difference in who falls first in an engagement. Although there are no fancy decapitation animations, it still rewards more of a sense of completion, since you know that you have to be powerful to slay this person or creature.
2) The Story
Oblivions many storylines, particulary the Dark Brotherhoods, blow skyrim out of the water. The characters have so much more depth than, I came from X and I'm gonna hostile to you now but after one ♥♥♥♥ing quest I'm gonna worship the ground you walk on" They will start to like you more after every few assassinations

reviewText:
This is probably the best Elder Scrolls game ever.

It has very nice looking graphics and all...
The main storyline is awesome.
There are several factions like The Dark Brotherhood, Thieves Guild, Mages guild and The Fighters Guild that you can join.
Also there is a lot of side guests to do.
There is an arena you go and fight on or then you can go and wager on it.
There is a lot looting to do and caves to rob...
You can also make your own potions, enchant items and make your own spells!
You can buy and decorate houses as you like or then you can just break into someone else's house and pretend it's yours...
You can get robbed too.
You can kill people stealthly with poison apples...
Or then you could just go hunting or just talk to everyone...
And if you have Game of the Year Edition Deluxe you will have many awesome DLC's too.

The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion: 10/10 Best game of 2006 and one of the best games of all time.

reviewText:
Mini-Review for Oblivion, requested by an user.

The question I've received: With skyrim having a great modding community, is there any reason to still pick up Oblivion?

Well, Yes. But allow me to explain.


Skyrim has the better graphics, better soundtrack, better combat, better ai, yada yada. All the stuff expected from having a better engine.
While vanilla oblivion in itself can offer you a lot:
A main quest that's of a grander scale as the one in Skyrim.
Far, far more side quests.
A plethora of explorable areas.
Actually more in-depth factions, reputations and guilds.
Better item distribution and item quality dispersion(when do you get this/that type).

Enfin, the real question is: All that vanilla stuff is great, but it can be modded into skyrim as well!
Well... Oblivion's mod-database is still far greater than the one skyrim has to offer as of now.
Graphics and Music can be easily improved, especially in the realm of character textures.
I'd personally also recommend many of the city overhauls and terrain improvements.
However, the real treats are in the more complex mods. Oblivion has had a far larger amount of time to develop it's mod pool and thus has far more complex mods for whatever tickles your fancies.

In short: If you're in love with modding your Bethesda games, Oblivion is certainly worth picking up and is easily moddable to your heart's content.
Even if you're not into modding the game itself holds its own unique charm and well worth experiencing, especially if it happens to go on sale!

So, hereby answering the request: Oblivion is a must have if you're fan of the TES series, well worth considering if you love modding games, worth a try if you started at skyrim and wondered what events lead to it, and if you're new to Bethesda's TES series a fair point to start.

~Rose

reviewText:
First off, I have over 300 hours in this game on Xbox so don't be fooled by my low playtime on steam. Secondly the fact that I have over 300 hours should tell you that this game is worth playing, if it isn't enough I break down what makes this such a great game and where its strengths and weaknesses are in this review.

Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is an open world role playing game that emphasizes on player freedom, exploration and creativity.  You play a prisoner of the imperial army who meets the emperor while he is trying to covertly get out of the city when a cult of assassins are killing members of the royal family to wipe out their bloodline. During the games tutorial you get recruited abruptly to help guard the emperor during this escape. Here you will get some insight on how to play the game and how the character progression system works as well as a taste of the lore of the elder scrolls universe. Once this brief but effective tutorial sequence is over you emerge a free man/woman free to do WHATEVER you want.  You can take part of all number of activities and explore the vast province of Cyrodil; you can sink hundreds of hours into this massive very in depth game.

The things you can do are extensive in Oblivion. There is the main story which is engrossing and varied though a little on the shorter side. There are four guilds you can join complete with their own quest lines which are all fantastic and very interesting with cool characters and feel distinctly different from each other. There is the Fighters Guild" the "Mages Guild" the "Thieves Guild" and the "Dark Brotherhood". There is also the arena where you engage in gladiator style fights with some of Cyrodil's greatest fighters and most viscous beasts. You can also visit shrines of the various gods in the game and do quests for them
date: these are some of the best in the game and all are unique and yield cool rewards. There is also a plethora of quest's to do for the citizens of Cyrodil which are amazingly mostly unique and quite fun. There are countless caves
hoursPlayed: and other locations to find and explore. There are houses through out the game you can buy and decorate ranging from shacks by the water the exquisite manors. Of course you can also spend hours on hours training your character and interacting with all the npc's in the game. The amount of content in this game feels endless and can be binge played all day
voteText: day after day with always more content seeming to pop up all over the place.\n\nOblivion takes place in Cyrodil as I mentioned earlier in the review
helpfulPercent: the central province in the continent of Tamriel. Cyrodil is the seat of imperial power where the Septim bloodline has reigned as emperor for generations. The Septim bloodline has a power
votesHelpful: related to the gods themselves and they now face being wiped out by a sinister cult whose motivations are dark and mysterious. The Elder Scrolls series is rich with lore
votesTotal: Bethesda invented gods both "good" and "evil" with personalities and beliefs all unique from each other. The relationships the gods have with mortals are very interesting. You can spend hours reading the various books in the game learning about Tamriels history and learn more about the various groups and their own history
votesFunny: it's insanely extensive.\n\nThe gameplay is an interesting but mixed bag. The graphics look dated
commentsCount: the animations are clunky and the voice cast is extremely small for a world with so many people in it but it's pretty easy to overlook with all the goes right in the game. For combat you can use melee weapons ranging from swords to maces to axes as well as ranged weapons like bows. Magic is also very prominent in combat as well as for utility in the game. Combat is kind of stiff at times but it works fine and is easy to get the hang of. The leveling system is one of the elder scrolls’ biggest strengths and weaknesses simultaneously. You level your character by leveling your skills
column16: these skills vary from "Blade Weapons" too "Lock picking". Leveling you skills increases your overall level
column17: so if you spending all your time leveling utility skills like "Alchemy" and "Athletics" but without leveling your combat skills like "Destruction" magic or "Archery" your character will be poor in combat which will make getting things done difficult. It’s also important to think clearly about what kind of character you want to make
column18: this will determine what skills you should focus on leveling in the early game
column19: once these skills are at an adequate level you can then branch out into other skills that are catch your interest. Leveling up other skills will allow making your character more malleable in different situations. Remember
column20: solving all your problems by swinging an axe into people's heads isn't the best way to handle all situations. Also all the music in the game is fantastic.\n\nIn the end
column21: when you take all the good and the bad together you have an imperfect but very awesome RPG. You can lose all your spare time for a long time with this game
column22: and you will love every minute of it. The two DLC's that the game of the year edition comes with

column24: the latter is one of the best DLC's I have ever played. It's like a whole game in itself almost. This is a fantastic experience and I would recommend it to anybody.\n\n9.5/10"

reviewText:
It's an amazing rpg, what more can I say? The graphs are overall good, combat is ok, and the setting is superb. Personally I feel this is one of the better roleplaying games out there, in terms of immersion. The character creation is especially detailed, allowing you to create complex and interesting characters.

The world is huge, but not so big that its overwhelming. Whenever I play this game I almost always have an interesting adventure with some kind of story, just from the complexity of the world. It's a game in which you can just play and enjoy, without relying solely on premade quests to keep you interested.

Overall I would strongly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Oblivion one of my favorite games of all time.
Morrowind is were it all began and Skyrim is the result of years of refinement, but Oblivion is the ambitious middle game
in the modern Elder Scrolls games.

Why?

I first started playing Oblivion about a year ago, this was after i played Skyrim.
When i first started the game it felt a little off. The controls were weird the graphics and the animations were a bit lame.
After i played it for a while i actualy noticed that this world felt much more alive than Skyrim.
I forgot the time and it really gave me the drive to explore the game.

The Quest were just unique from one another and there wasn't a single quest i thought was boring.
When i was deep in the game i forgot about the animations and realised i actualy liked the graphics from Oblivion more.
They are much more alive instead of all the depressing and boring snow from Skyrim.
In terms of physical appearance Skyrim is ofcourse alot better, and well it does look nice but i actualy like the positive environment from Oblivion more.

Its just such an awesome and fun game even today.
You just have to get into it, and when you do you will not get out.
I never know what to expect in this game and it always keeps me excited.
If you have the money go buy it, i am so glad i started it once when i just was bored.
Its totally worth it!

Oblivion
- Awesome questing
- 14 Guilds
- Positive and nice environment
- Fun Combat
- Amazing Soundtrack

For an old game, it just never ceases to amaze me every single time.

reviewText:
This is honestly my favorite Elder Scrolls game. Its a perfect balance between not holding your hand as much as Skyrim but also occasionally cutting you some slack should you want it. You can still break the game, but its not necessary, its something that you have to want to do.

The enviornments are beautiful. My personal favorite. Really nice fantasy enviornments with varying flora and fauna and color schemes. When you're in the north sections, it feels cool and then cold and rocky, when you're in the southwest, it feels like warm rolling plains surrounded with flowers, in the east it feels like a trecherous swamp. Imo there isn't a Elder Scrolls game out with more attention to the sheer atmosphere of whatever setting you're in.

Combat isn't anything in depth (it isn't in Skyrim or Morrowind either though, so don't kid yourself), but its all pretty balanced and you can play mostly anything exactly how you'd expect. Do I wish daggers had more backstab damage? Sure. Is conjuration a bit on the strong side? Yep. But if you want to make an archer you can make just an archer. If you just want to punch things, that works too. The game has a really good amount of challenge to me, and doesn't become suddenly easier when you reach a ceartin milestone (as in Morrowind), and doesn't forget to present any challenge unless you really mess up your character (as in Skyrim).

People say the game needs mods, but I don't really agree. I would reccomend installing a face overhaul, yeah. Its a rough part of the awkward 2006 graphics era. But other than that the fantasy setting does it well enough where you don't need any hyper realitic immaculate textures in my opinion at least.

So I dunno what else to say without rambling. I love Morrowind and Skyrim, I really do. But Oblivion will always have a special place in my heart, and if you aren't too diehard devoted the modern luxuries that Skyrim offers, or the somewhat hardcore trpg influenced gameplay that Morrowind has, this is a wonderful game.

Also; the soundtrack. Easily one of my favorites out of any game.

reviewText:
The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion... Maybe one of the greatest game's ever to be released. Made by Bethesda Softworks you can expect alot of bugs. Yet, you will see alot of adventure and interresting dialogue. The game's story is that the gates to Oblivion (AKA hell) has opened in Cyrodill, and you. A prisoner off the Imperial Prison needs to seek a way out off the prison with the Emperor, and also find the last heir to him and shut close the jaws of oblivion. The game has a great atmosphere and it has alot of enjoyable colors aswell. The areas are simply beautfull, you always feel the need to explore the open world and also help the people around you when you actually listen to all their problems.

When playing you will see alot of NPC's, some NPC's will only be talkable during quests or guilds. Or they might have a quest or just be people that are there to fill the area. There is about four guilds in the game, following the Thieves Guild, Dark Brotherhood, Mage's College/Mage's Guild, and ofcourse Fighters Guild.

The story off the Dark Brotherhood is that you have just been spyed on by a man when you have killed a innocent, he will tell you to kill a man (Not saying due to spoilers) when you have done so you are invited. But to the guild you will be nothing but just a new member. You do quests to advance and aqually mean something in the guild.

The Thieves Guild is similiar to the Dark Brotherhood in the sneaking aspect. But you can't kill people as that gives you a boun ty. The story follows: You have been thrown in jail, the people off the thieves guild take you as a criminal now and has given you a chance to join the group. You start off as a normal low ranked member, not being of much use, but it will change when you become a higher rank.

The story of the Mage's Guild is self explanatory. Mage's Against some evil people. This guild is the most boring one in my opinion, but if you're playing  a mage I recommend this guild.

The Fighter's Guild, this one is very mixed for me... it didn't have much for a story except for stop that guy, do that, stop that guy. But was still very interesting and had alot of fun moments.

Overall, the Elder Scrolls: Oblivion in the ends turns out as a great adventure game with alot off challenge and alot of fun, you will spend about possibly even 90 hours trying to complete everything or less if you just wanna finish the story, but then you're just missing out off the actual game. As the game is very good and still has quite decent graphics compared to some games. I give this game a 9.5 out of 10 due to how it was made and how much there is to do. The graphics aren't the greatest but are actually quite decent. This game is very recommended from me if you like adventure and RPG mashed togheter.

reviewText:
Once the dust had settled I tried Oblivion for the first time in close to a decade, and I found a game I really didn't hate anymore.

Oblivion strikes the balance between depth (Morrowind) and playability (Skyrim). It features very well designed quests and far more improved combat. With a world that is full of color, and a wide assortment of locations. From snowy plateaus to sandy beaches filled with twitchy Argonians.

At the same time the game is still flawed. It's a game that hasn't aged very well graphically, and the RPG elements are very hamfisted and lacking. There are thankfully mods that fix all of this, and I don't recommend playing this game vanilla. If you do, all you'll find is a game filled with potato people. One where you are legitimately stronger at the beginning of the game due to how badly coded the levelling system is.
