reviewText:
The first time i played this game was somewhere around 2009 or 10 for PS3, after being hooked on Fallout 3 i thought that this game was going to be just as awesome and time consuming, but it was difficult for me to get hooked as i did not understand the lore to this game much. Fast-forward to 2011 when i got my copy of Skyrim i found that i was able to play an Elder Scrolls game, and i found it to be one of the best games i have ever played, and went well over the 300 hours of gameplay estimated for the game.

After playing Skyrim i chose to play Oblivion again, and i loved it. After having a bit of knowledge on the lore and the way Elder Scrolls games worked i found that the world of Tamriel became a more interesting, and definitely beautiful place, but i never did complete Oblivion until today on the PC. (18/10/2014)

I can tell that Cyrodiil is very much based on England, or countries alike; with the vast and beautiful forests to explore to the rolling fields and meadows of County Skingrad and The West Weald, i felt like i had taken a journey back in time to the days of Albion, where tales of magic, dragons and heros were told in regular supply. The experience of delving into the past in Ancient Ayleid Ruins was exciting and jumpy, and all the more rewarding once you come out with a good bit of loot, gold, and tons of welkynd stones... maybe too many, but aside from the visuals and personal experience, i found the story to be very much like the fantasy stories of gold, and i cannot believe i never took the time to follow the main storyline before, but alas, i have now completed it.

There are a few letdowns however, one being the lack of variety in voices for NPCs, and the very static movement of the animations for the game. I admit this was made back in 2005 and was BGS' second major 3D game, i think, but it made the game quite immersion breaking at times, and nobody would want to be pulled out of this amazing world. Speaking of voice acting, there were times where the voice acting for certain characters were not on par with the voice acting of the regular NPCs, and i found this to be disappointing with the amount of quality this game tries to bring to the table.

Graphically this game has a very artistic feel to it, for where it wants to be as realistic as possible, it still has a sense of handmade effort in the visuals that gives what you see value, because the world of Cyrodiil is like looking at a painting: a true masterpiece.

So my final rating for this game is a very strong 9.2/10

Before entering the world of Tamriel, i recommend looking up on some of the lore, i would recommend ShoddyCast on YouTube with it's lore series, but this game, and Skyrim, are a definite purchase.

reviewText:
The king of kings in the fantasy gaming community. This game series defined what a fantasy world should be like and is the foundation of any good fantasy RPG. Though it seems old to many young gamers, this game is a must have for any gamer that loves fantasy settings.

Each race in Oblivion has its own strengths and weaknesses, greatly defining each race and seperating them from everyone else. For instance, Bretons (A race in Oblivion) can wield powerful magics and start off with more magical energies than other races, though they are weaker than most. Khajit can sneak around more easily and can use their claws as weapons to hurt their foes.

There are many different classes in this game, each one serving a certain role. Do you want a warrior who also uses magic? Or would you rather prefer and rouge that uses illusions to hide his tracks as he steals jewels? If you don't like any of the classes, there is an option where you can create your own class, tailoring it to your own needs and wants. Combining a magic wielding class with a race that specilizes in certain classes of magics will allow you to become the greatest mage in the world or creating a two handed wielding orc to become the most feared barbarian in the lands.

And the fun doesn't stop there, each adventure is more interesting than the last. One play through may have you encounter a door to Oblivion where you must close the door before more demons pour through. Another play through may have you collect a strange weed with mystical powers. No play through is ever the same.

If you haven't played Oblivion and you are interested in Fantasy Settings, then Oblivion is a must have in your library.

reviewText:
Oblivion is the sequal to the critically acclaimed TES 3 Morrowind, and predessessor to the well-known Skyrim (TES 5). This time it is set in Cyrodiil, the Imperial Province of lush forests, snowy mountain caps and dark swamps, all to be explored at will. There are nine major cities, Anvil, Kvatch, Skingrad, Chorral, Bravil, Leyawin, Bruma, Cheydinhal and the Imperial City, plus many other minor settlements, temples, farms etc.

Right at after character creation, you are taken by the Emporers guards on an escape from the palace dungeons, before he tasks you with delivering the Amulet of Kings and shutting closed the jaws of Oblivion. From then on you have the entire province to explore at your own will. You can join guilds such as the fighters guild, basically the legal vigilanties of Tamriel, the mages guild, who are basically the wizards of the empire, the thieves guild, which is an illegal guild of robbers and thieves, the dark brotherhood, who are the spiritual assassins who worship Sithis and the Night Mother, and the Arena, which is pretty self explanetory.

A good understanding of TES lore is recommended, and will always make the game feel more real. I recommend this series to bring you up to speed. https://www.youtube.com/user/ShoddyCast It will inform you on the many races, religions, provinces and more that exist on Nirn (It also explains what Nirn is). Or you could read the many ingame books as an alternative.

The only downsides I can think of is the chat system, which is a little outdated, and the stupid essential NPCs. Unforunatly they removed Morrowinds 'you can kill anyone, as long as you can deal with the consequences' system in favor of appeal to casual gamers. These don't damage the overall game too much, however.

9.1/10

reviewText:
Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is one of those games where you can fully immerse yourself within it's environment and society. The world (called Cyrodiil)  has multiple regions of landscape, all giving you a taste of wildlife and roleplaying elements, like old, swampy caves or a great fort in the uplands of Colovia. Everywhere you go you can interact with the environment, from plants and mushrooms to animals and NPCs.

When you open the grate out of the sewer for the first time you realise the immense beauty of lake rumare, but thats the tip of the iceberg. You could if you wish, follow the main quest, and complete it how the developers thought it would be like. Or you can find your own path venture into an unknown cave, or explore the Imperial City's marketplace and see what it has to offer.

The game has oppertunities to be each class as you will, and a race to go along with it. You could be a High Elf Mage, the Arch-Mage of the Arcane University, or a Nordic Warrior, leader of the Fighters guild. There is a great range of quests to complete and level up your character. You may want to find certain items and loot dungeons to find them, while selling what else you find.

The Shivering Isle DLC, lets Sheogorath the Daedric Prince of Madness invite you to his realm, where everything is run a whole lot differently. The Knights of Nine DLC sends you on an epic quest, to defeat Umaril, who threatens Cyrodiil, while worshipping the Nine Divines. Depending on which pack you brought, one edition will come with four DLC houses, each with their own quest, and some other miscellaneous DLC.

So go explore Cyrodiil in all its glory. Be a Warrior, or a Thief, or a Mage or even all of them together! Thats the thing with Oblivion, its an inviting world at your fingertips that will never get old.

However they could patch up on the Havok Physics a bit.

reviewText: Say what you will about the repetitive oblivion gates and the potato face character models, this game is a triumph in open-world gaming.  Radiant AI makes the game feel much more alive than previous Elder Scrolls installments.  The Dark Brotherhood faction remains the single most intruiging questline I have ever played in a game.  You will hear npcs telling rumors of events that you yourself participated in, making you feel that your actions have had some impact in the world.    The Shivering Isles expansion that comes with this game is probably the best DLC I have ever played.  It is arguably a tighter experience than the base game.  Morrowind fans will likely experience a bit of nostalgia from the alien landscapes featured.  This game's only real problem is that everything that it tries to do doesn't always work as intended.  This is most obvious with how npcs interact both with you, and with each other.  You can have a perfectly pleasant conversation with an npc, only for him to tell you to shut up and leave him alone when you say your goodbyes.  While this is oftentimes comical, it is also immersion breaking, which is a bit hit for a game whose biggest draw is making you feel like an inhabitant in a living world.  Also, dungeons can feel a little repetitive, as designs are often reused.  It's hard to have every dungeon feel unique when there are so many of them in the game, but I would still expect a bit more variety than what we got.  I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys rpgs or open world games.  The amount of solid content you're getting for 20 dollars or less is incredible, and should not be passed up.

reviewText: In my opinion, Oblivion is the best out of all 5 of the games in the series. And did I mention PATRICK DAMN STEWART!?\n\nWith all that said, the number one reason why this is better than Skyrim is: in what the heck other game can you go on a bloodthirsty massacre across the countryside and get off with a slap on the wrist, but get sent to rot away in prison for months for merely touching a noble's tweezers!? (.....and Patrick Stewart, we can't forget about him.,....)

reviewText:
I only have three hours clocked in on Steam, but on the 360, I've probably spent hundreds of hours of my freshman year in high school walking against a wall to build up my sneak skill.

Oblivion was my gateway back into the world of RPG's after I had strayed off into the void of CoD and similar titles. A friend of my older brother had let us borrow a handful of games for the 360, and this was one of them. While my brother didn't touch it, I took the leap and tried it out. It was love at first sight.

And I'm 99% sure that I never gave it back to the guy.

Anyways, everyone looking at this game is probably comparing it against Skyrim: which should I buy? My answer is definitely both, they're both worth the money. I've literally bought both of these games twice, putting my investment into these games close to 200 bucks, and I don't regret it, not even a little bit, but if you have to choose between one or the other, here are the pro's and con's for both games.

Oblivion:
+Hundreds of hours of gameplay
+Highly replayable
+Great character customization
+Great storyline
+Great not-storyline, seriously, just wander into some town and you can
go days before you remember that the world is in chaos
+I personally like the alchemy and speech functions in this game, but I
know some don't
+Spell crafting, OMG!!!!

-Graphics are now dated
-On Steam, there is no controller interface :-(
-No dual-wielding

Skyrim
+Hundreds of hours of gameplay
+Highly replayable
+Great character customization
+Great storyline
+Great not-storyline, same as above
+Dual wielding
+DRAGONS!!!
+Very deep-running political agendas in-game
+SMITHING

reviewText:
Although I may view other games as being objectively better, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is the single-player game I will always go back to. It is more than a game to me. I view it as true Post-Modern art and something of a lifestyle choice.

Bethesda tried to recreate little parts of reality in the interactions between customized NPCs and their scheduled AI. They failed horribly and created instead listless deformed humanoids that lack the intelligence to do little more than bump into one another and echo the same conversation they heard from their previous collision. They lack the social awareness not to steal apples in front of a crowd of guards, nonchalantly stumble over corpses in the town square, or calmly approach a man wearing the recently murdered Emperor's robes.

These NPCs do not resemble human beings at all, questionably apart from their character models. They are insane, compulsive, and often ghoulish creatures. (Searching through random NPC houses will commonly unearth dead bodies, Dread Father shrines, and other signs of repulsive activity.) It is inspiring in a way to see a thing so close yet so distant in reference to human society.

Bethesda realized all of this in a moment of unbearably historic revelation and started work on the game that marks their Self-Actualization -- Shivering Isles. The people of Sheogorath's realm, the Shivering Isles, are each driven mad and suffer from individualistic fixations. Creating a society of manic and demented people is precisely what Bethesda was meant to do with their perfect skillset of brilliant writing, AI that requires specific targets and times, awkward character animations, and ugly models. Instead of accidently creating a weird RPG, they intentionally directed their labor to the highest-valued function. Shivering Isles is absolutely entertaining to explore as a result. Also, Wes Johnson's Sheogorath leaves such an impression on me.

As a whole, there is an impossible amount of content to experience. For nearly 10 years of consistent play, every new game has revealed new quests (some that don't appear in the journal) that I somehow missed. The quests are consistently hilarious and even have expanded my vocabulary. Exploring is vastly rewarding, as you can discover schedules, backgrounds, and dark secrets of NPCs. There are a fair amount of treasure and unique items hidden about the world, as well. (This is unlike Skyrim's limited content that ends in repeating quests and NPCs that reveal all there is to know about themselves in 20 minutes of town dialogue.) As the NPCs have priority-based AI, they will often interact with one another in surprising ways and result in laugh riots. The dungeons are cookie-cutter and rumors are oft repeated. The combat is stupid, but if you are playing Oblivion for the combat...(LOL). The clothes and armor are not as pretty and differentiated as Morrowind's, but you can still make a few cute outfits. If any of Oblivion's shortcomings bother you that much, though, you can mod the game. ;)

I unfortunately lost my disc 1 while moving, so I repurchased Oblivion on Steam recently. Thus far, this edition works properly on my Windows 7 and comes with Shivering Isles and the objectively trash Knights of the Nine thing. I finished KotN in one brief sitting, had no use for the rewards at my level (like 30), and was rather bored throughout. That's fine, tho', because Shivering Isles alone is worth the MSRP of this product. Heck, even just the soundtrack is worth the MSRP.

reviewText:
I cannot even begin to explain the massiveness of this game.  Very much like Skyrim it is completely open world, RPG brilliance.  From the very start the choices you make, and quests you complete start to define your character for the hero they will become.  Right off the bat i am going to give this game a 9/10.

Story:  Oblivions story is centralized around the idea that Tamriel is in chaos because the emperor was mmurdered, and without a new emperor to light the dragonfires cyrodill will fall into darkness.  In addition to this massive panic towards the death of the emperor, Oblivion gates (Virtually gates to hell) start opening up all across the province.  It is your job to go in and destroy these gates, and crown the new emperor for Cyrodill.

Factions:  I have to say that this is possibly one of the best faction systems in any game.  contrasted only by Skyrim.  The way it is set up allows for multiple factions at once, and allow you to become the almighty ruler of them all.  The factions are: Mages Guild, Fighters Guild, Dark Brotherhood, Thieves Guild, and The Arena, other lower end factions also exist but these are the ones with the most quests involved.  Each of these has a seperate unique storyline that from time to time will also cross into other factions.  Quite revelating.

Visual Appeal:  My computer has an I5 processor and was able to handle almost everything on completely high res (with the exception of shadows and sometimes water), but with that in mind, and the fact that this game was released in 2006...8 YEARS OLD, its still incredibly beautiful!!  The view of the landscape that tranistions from Grasslands, to forests, to the jerall mountains, to the swampy regions of Leyawiin...Takes my breath away.  Though other Elder Scrolls games primarily focused on one regions appeal, morrowind to swamp, and skyrim more to snow, this game perfectly incorporated all regions as it was central bound.

Gameplay:  This games main focus revolves around classes that fight in unique way, while also simaltaneously questing.  These mechanics are very strikingly similar to the Legend of Zelda, and if you have ever played a Zelda game, you know perfectly well how exquisetly it accomplishes this.  There are three basic classes, warrior, mage, and thief.  All three of these have their attriubtes, but the remarkable thing about this game is that you can freely choose what you want!  Though choosing your base class at the beginning with determine what skills you are more adept at, you are still able to combine any skills with any other skills.  If you want to be a battleaxe wielding, light armored elf with excellent conjuration skills. You are able to do that no problem.  This system allows you to perfectly mould out your character to what you feel would suit you best.

Quests:  If you do somehow manage to beat all quests in the game, then sir i owe you a gold medal.  If i recall correctly i believe there are around 500 quests in the game to do.  Which some can be completed by simply delivering a package, while others like the main quest will make you toy around for 10 hours before being completed.  The multitude of quests in this game is astounding, and will have your interest hooked for the long haul.

Final Impressions:  Oblivion is by far my favorite fantasy game of all time let alone my actual favorite game of all time.  I personally own about 5 different versions of the game because of my love for it.  Though it says on my steam profile i only have 9 hours on PC, i had approximately 50 hours on my other steam account, and on xbox...i would be baffled if it said anything less than 600.  This game has a deep connection with me because of Bethesdas brilliance to bring forth such a revolutionary game such as this one.  Even if this genre is something you cant see yourself getting into, i challenge you to play at least the tutorial, join a single faction, and kill a baddie or two and tell me it hasnt captured your interest like it did mine.  In conclusion this is an amazing game and a must buy for every person who has steam.

reviewText: The Elder Scrolls IV is a game that is munch between The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind's gaming legacy and the extremely popular Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim. Many people would ask, Should I get (or still get) the Elder Scrolls IV? Of course.\n\nOblivion is well known for its scenery, extensive side questlines, and a remarkable story. The game has aged and its skill system will make newcomers rage (the skill system is mediocre at best, but it not really good). Oblivion was one of the first role-playing game that I've purchased for the Xbox 360 back in 2006. The game was really popular back then with so much things to do. Spend hours exploring caves and dungeons. Become the Grand Champion in the Imperial Arena. Become the Grandmaster for the Mages Guild, the Leader of the Fighters Guild, the Master of Thieves for the Thieves Guild. Each character you encounter would have a unique personality and would have a quest for you to do. The soundtrack for the game is absolutely the best and it would make you just sit and relax just to listen. There are varieties of environments in the game, ranging from the spring-like setting, the pouring rain in the southern side of the map, to the blistering cold in Northern Cyrodiil. If the setting of Skyim makes you a bit...dull" (meaning that you are tired of playing  the dominated wintery and snowy map of Skyrim)
date: you can come back to Oblivion where all kinds of weather is featured in one game. Like other Elder Scrolls games
recommended: Oblivion should be in your gaming library. For gamers that had played Oblivion before
hoursPlayed: its time to return to Cyrodiil."

reviewText:
Oblivion was great for its time. Released in 2006, that was the year before I graduated high school and attempted college. I played it to death and back on the Xbox, probably netting a few hundred hours. I remember getting the manual and reading it in class, like it was any other textbook.

Now I've recently returned to it, several years later with an improved computer and modding capabilities and it does breathe some life into the game. While I can agree that Oblivion, by itself, has not aged well... It helps to mod it up to increase resolution, textures, and getting a mod to make everyone's faces look a lot more... normal. Doing all of that, it's like coming back to an old (but prettier) friend.

Shivering Isles also continues to be a fairly fun expansion to play through. With two whole armor sets to work towards, dungeons with great loot, and a main quest that is extremely rewarding in terms of magical powers and loot, it's great to play through once more. (Incidentally, SI is also the most stable part of the game. Not a single Crash-to-Desktop or bug to be found while I was running around the Isles. Perhaps I was lucky, but perhaps the expansion just runs that well).

I can understand how newer aged gamers may not care for the game too much... But Oblivion is worth exploring for some retroactive nostalgia if you started this franchise with Skyrim. Play this, and I'd also recommend Morrowind while you're at it.
Happy gaming!

reviewText:
I can still remember when I first got The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. My older cousin was playing it, and after only 20 minutes of running around as his character, I was utterly hooked. I was about...16 years old? Perhaps younger?
The game itself is, for it's time, revolutionary, and it pioneered an entirely new kind of open world RPG, with 'no' invicible walls except for the required ones to put a limit on the generated world. Other then that, every door, was accessible somehow, and every plot of land was reachable. There was not a direction you could not go in Oblivion, and as an RPG, that made it priceless.
The game also hosts rather higher tier voice acting. For example, Patrick Stewart(Also famous for starring as Xavier in X-Men, and Captain Jean Luc Picard in Star Trek: The Next Generation), lays voice to the majestic Emperor Uriel Septim, whom you meet during the tutorial of the game.
The game, for customization, offers an impressive array of possibilities, with multiple races, hair styles, and direct face molding sliders to make you look truly unique(Or outright silly). It also offers a believably long winded skill system that permits you to become more talented in certain professions and skills as you perform them.
As with most Bethesda developped games, Oblivions Engine is uniquely compatible with 3rd party Modification software, allowing Mesh, Animation, and Scripting artists etc. to work almost entirely independantly in the game, limited only by the game's graphical capabilities, and their own imagination. The amount of modifications(Or mods) released for Oblivion, is vast, but has since been passed by its successor; The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim(I should mention that Oblivion by storyline standards, happens 400 years before Skyrim does, and takes place in the Tamrielian province of Cyrodil, the homeland of the Imperials)
Some individuals will argue that Oblivion is unplayable without mods, but I must say, Oblivion is one of the only games released by Bethesda that is truly a remarkable, fulfilled, well thought out and extremely precisely and expertly executed video game that by no means requires mods to be playable.
On a scale of 10 hearts? I give Oblivion an 8.5 hearts. The game's higher tier voice actors, coupled with its engaging story, and the impressive free roam oppertunity, the large cult following and the engaging, high quality modding community, this game is, in on itself, a culture, and I would dare to say that you cannot call yourself a gamer without having walked the adventure filled, dangerously beautiful landscapes of Tamriel, and its many unique provinces.

reviewText:
The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Game of the Year Deluxe Edition

Be prepared for a detailed review of this game. If you're considering purchasing this, have a read and see what you think before doing so!

Positives:

+ Pleasant graphics for a game almost a decade old (2006).
+ A huge assortment of quest to complete, such as the Thieves' Guild, Dark Brotherhood, Fighter's Guild, Mage's Guild and Daedric God storylines. Lots of miscellaneous quests too.
+ Massive map to explore, lots of locations including caves, bandit camps, forts and ancient ayleid ruins. Snowy regions and lush forest, open grasslands and swamps, very varied terrain.
+ Wide array of weaponry, many, many skills to level up, use magic, archery or melee combat to strike down foes. Mix your own potions with alchemy, become a master of acrobatics or conjure powerful beasts to do your bidding.
+ Hundreds of hours of gameplay to engage in. Fun for the first 100-120. Anything in excess of level 40 starts to see boredom set in. I recommend taking regular breaks to avoid the repetition, in which case it won't be so noticeable.
+ Large mod community.

Negatives:

- Extremely flawed and stupid monster levelling, giving you no sense accomplishment when you progress to higher levels. Many creatures will be levelled to you, meaning that, at higher levels, you'll be required to spam click attacks for ages to get kills (ogres, goblin warlords, gloom wraiths). Keep in mind this is using the best weapons available, with the highest skill level. Much to your disdain, you'll spend hours clearing out caves or forts filled with insanely high hitpoint enemies. Not fun, not a challenge, just a complete and utter waste of time.
- Caves, dungeons and other places have a lot of loot potential and you'll have fun in the beginning collecting fragments of armour, potions and gold to pay for adventuring supplies and purchasing houses. However, after awhile there's literally nothing to spend your cash on. All of the equipment I've sold has resulted in stockpiling over 300,000 coins, with nothing practical to spend it on. Every elder scrolls (even the latest instalment to the series, Skyrim) has had this issue.

- Dumb AI that gets stuck when you jump onto rocks and cast magic or shoot arrows. It doesn't understand how to reach you. The AI scripting for conversations is also ridiculous. There are only a limited number of discussions citizens can have between each other and these all feel very, very unnatural. It's as if the designers didn't bother to implement realistic dialogue.
- Many textures for forts or caves are re-used and do not look unique. This gets dull later, rather than sooner, but it's still a great downfall of the title. The layouts of many locations are similar. They might have different pathways, include an underwater cave or a bridge, but for all intents and purposes, most locations have a familiar feel to them. There's little excitement in that regard.
- Modding requires excessive use of complicated tools that are not only time consuming but annoying. Not to mention the countless glitches that conflict with gameplay.
- Character levelling comes to a sudden halt around levels 40+, it becomes so infrequent that you feel like you're achieving nothing at all, apart from going on errands for a number of characters you don't care much about.

The Shivering Isles Expansion:

Positives:

+ New textures compared to the base game, an entirely new environment, new colours, new armour and weapons, new characters, new monsters and new quests. Consequently, this expansion does have a feeling of freshness to it.
+Around 30 hours of additional content, which is not unreasonable for an expansion.

Negatives:

- Despite the fact that there are various changes and new features, the dreadful monster levelling system remains, which never fails to detract greatly from the experience (unless you go to the Shivering Isles at a lower level, at which point it becomes bearable).
- Rather horrible voice acting for Sheogorath, too try-hard in its approach, quite off-putting and didn't seem like a genuine portrayal of the characteristics the developers wanted to exhibit, which was a God of Madness.

Knights of the Nine Expansion:

+ A new and intriguing storyline (for the most part) based around the Nine Divines, where you must complete a series of tests to retrieve the ancient armour of Crusader Pelinal Whitestrake, in an effort to defeat the infamous Umaril, a Daedra who poses a threat to Cyrodiil.
+ Some extra locations to explore which have been added to the map during the expansion, but nothing really new other than aesthetics (the Crusader armour and weapons).
+ There's a real feeling of reviving the old Knights of the Nine Order, as people will approach you to swear their allegiance. You'll fight side by side at the end against Umaril's minions in a big battle, which is cool.

Negatives:

- Many of the places you'll visit are filled with the standard enemies you'll encounter in the base game, there is little difference in the design of these locations to other ayleid ruins or forts in the base game as well.

DLC Add-Ons

Positives:

+ A number of new houses for those interested. There's a Wizard's Tower, a Castle and an underground Cave that can become new homes, some of them include enchanting and spellmaking areas for convenience.
+ A few additional activities to partake in, like collecting dwarven artifacts stolen by bandits, to repair an Orrery at the Arcane University. You can also investigate the caverns beneath anvil to find the resting place of a pirate ship and the mystery behind it. In the East of Cyrodiil you can travel to Sundercliff Watch, a fortress that holds the powerful Daedric item, Mehrune's Razor.

Negatives:

- Some bugs which interfere with how the house DLC works, causing problems with them being unable to be purchased or relevant questlines not progressing.

Overall Score: 7.5/10

The Elder Scrolls: IV Oblivion is almost a decade old as of 2015. It's still a very entertaining and fun game, but one should also be aware of the numerous problems it has. Worth picking up on sale for under $10.

reviewText: Oblivion is a great game with some large problems. It has good enough graphics and a good story, with well-done guild missions and beautiful cities. Oblivion also has one of my favorite soundtracks, with music style changing based on where you go or who you meet. There is a lot to explore, such as Shivering Isles, and even more with mods. These add up to create very memorable moments; however, like all games, there are problems. The outdoor areas in this game are usually extremely bland and boring, making exploration repetitive after a few hours. You will not see all the varied landscapes such as in Skyrim, each one hand-crafted and beautiful. The enemies level up as you do, so you will not find rewards by leveling up. When you are level 5, bandits may have weak armor and weapons; when you are level 20, they have tough armor and good weapons. You will find them in very formulated patterns, such as when you walk along a trail and see each enemy standing the same distance away from each other, each one standing motionless in the middle of the trail. This makes the game feel less realistic. That leads me to the game's biggest fault; the combat. Combat is literally bonkers compared to Skyrim. Enemies soak arrows and take hits like a sponge. In Skyrim, I could take down an enemy fairly quickly by sneaking behind them and slitting their throat, I could take someone down with a few arrows, and I could kill with a few hits of a sword. In Oblivion, I can recall shooting about ebony twenty arrows (at least) from an ebony bow into a bear until it finally died. It took about 15 ebony arrows from an ebony bow and 10 flare spells (very weak) to kill a bandit. However, it is easy to enjoy the game while acknowledging these faults. Don't think the bad outweighs the good, because it doesn't. Oblivion is a great game, and if it had a good leveling system, combat, and hand-crafted environments, it would be the best Elder Scrolls game.

reviewText:
This game embodies what every open world game should be, the ability to choose how much of the main story and which elements you want to follow. You could do a mix of main and side quests as I do on most of my playthroughs. Another option is to only pursue the main quest line, and then once that's finished, delve into the rest of the world. Or you could choose to ignore the main quest entirely and play 40+ hours of interesting side quests fleshing out the rich, beautiful world the characters inhabit and then come back to the main quest line only once you've explored the entire rest of the world.

I would also suggest looking into mods once you've played through the game a time or two as this could add hundreds of hours of gameplay, scenery, and characters that are as good or better than the quality of the original game.

(Although I'm new to this game on steam, I've played hundreds of hours on my original physical copy.)

reviewText:
If you are planning to buy the game be sure to get the Oblivion GOTY deluxe edition to avoid the disappointing discovery that you missed out on some DLC. There is no legit way to upgrade from the 'normal' GOTY to the GOTY deluxe version besides buying the whole game a second time.

As Todd Howard said in an interview about Oblivion: 'We made the game for hardware that doesn't exist.' Ten years after release that turns out to be a good thing. You can play Oblivion in 4k right out of the box and it looks pretty good with all settings on ultra high. If you invest a little time in modding the visuals are on par with Skyrim.
Don't take complaints about the dated graphics to seriously as more often than not the underwhelming hardware is to blame.

Like in the other games of the TES series you face a huge open world and the main quest being not stellar is not bad either.
But the main quest is not what most players love to do in an Elder Scrolls game. It is the masterfully created living and breathing world with hundreds of side quests that keep you playing for hours and hours with always something new to do for you. And some of the quests are really memorable and I would go so far as to say the best in the franchise.

The soundtrack by Jeremy Soule is spot on and one of the best you'll hear in any game. Shivering Isles is the best expansion I've ever played. See? I could go on and on.

I should at least mention the massive content the modding community has contributed over the years. Giving you many more hours of enjoyment.

All this can be yours for a few Septims - I mean €/$. You owe it to yourself to try it out if you are into RPGs. Oblivion is not a perfect game by any means - but it is very good and a technical masterpiece.

reviewText:
I'm going to start off this review by saying that I've played this game from a disc since the year it came out (so pretty much for ten years lol)  and only recently got the steam version, so I would say I have 2000 hours + on this game. So I know what I'm talking about when I talk about this game.

Character Customization
The customization is great and leaves you with infinite possibilities to making a character.
There are 21 skills and 8 attributes in Oblivion, allowing you to customise a class and a birthsign to give boots to certain skills and aspects of your character.
This brings me onto the  leveling system
At the start (when you choose a class) you can choose seven skills to be your Major skills". You will get a +20 boost in each one and you will level up these skills much faster.
Also
date:
upgrading these skills allows you to progress to your characters next level. You can now upgrade your attributes based on the skills you learn.

Story/Quests
This game is story rich and you will absolutely fall in love with it if you like RPGs.
The main quest itself is epic and will take you a while to finish
recommended: But the game has SO much more than that (not to mention DLC).\nWith 200 + unique quests it will take you years to fully complete this game and even when you have
hoursPlayed:
there's always Knights of the Nine and the Shivering Isles which add so much more to the game.

Graphics/Visuals
Obviously this game is no match for Skyrim and GTA V but the graphics are amazing for 2006 standards
voteText: and are still alright for today's standards.\nThis game looks great in terms of landscape
helpfulPercent: it's full of colour and very vibrant. (In my opinion it looks better than skyrim)\nBut overall this game's graphics are pretty good and the general visuals of this game are very appealing
votesHelpful:
and you can run the game on a toaster.

Soundtrack
This game's soundtrack is one of the best out there IMO. The main theme of this song is instantly recognisable and very fitting to the story. (The opening cutscene still gives me chills when I first hear the main theme)

Interface
You can enter the main interface by hitting Tab. This contains your Inventory
votesTotal: Spell menu
votesFunny: Journal
commentsCount: Map and an overview of your skills. Each category is like a drop down menu
column16:
which is very easy to navigate.

Modding
Modifying this game is very easy and mods can easily be activated and deactivated in the launch menu. Some recommended mods:
- Midas Magic
- The Lost Spires
- Cheidenhall Pet Shop
- Rebuild Kvatch

DLC
Buying DLCs adds so much more to the game
column17: though i would only recommend the Shivering Isles and maybe the Knights of the Nine.\nThe Shivering Isles is like another entire game. It has a completely different world (you can easily travel between the two using a portal)

column20: and of course quests

column24: the insane ruler of the Isles.\nI would give TSI 9/10.\nThe Knights of the Nine is pretty much just another main quest added to the game

and I'm not going to lie it's pretty fun. I would give it a 7.5/10

SUMMARY (THANKS FOR READING THIS FAR)
This game is simply everythig you could ask for in an RPG. It's exciting

With adjustable difficulty you can learn the game pretty easily.\nI would completely 100% recommend this to anyone. It's just an all-round good game. If you are buying it I would recommend the shivering Isles too

reviewText: Only got this on steam cos my disk copy stopped working. Been playing since it was released in 2006, and I can safely say that Oblivion is easily the best Elder Scrolls game. It's a more complex and deep than Skyrim could ever be, but also better looking and it's game mechanics are easier to understand than Morrowinds, and none of the frustrating combat. Also IMO has the best music of the series, and it is also the only game in the series to let you have true free reign in creating your character. All the games before only let you select from a limited number of faces, while Skyrim only lets you choose presets. Oblivion has sliders which can change the shape of every part of the face. This lets you create some true masterpieces" of character design: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=696164598 The storyline is also great (and doesn't have the bad ending of Skyrim) and with the Shivering isles expansion you get even more crazy. Oblivion
recommended: also gives you the ability to create you own spells which is great fun. Only things that are worse in Oblivion are the graphics (obviously)

reviewText: One of the best RPGs that I've ever played. You will have plenty of fun with this game and once you beat it vanilla, it's time to install mods! Mods for this game are soooo much fun. Anything that you can think of, they add to the game. Want new quests? Done. Want rebalancing of level? Easy. Do you want more weapons? How about a mod that adds 120 immersive weapons? Yes, there are many, many mods for this game.\n\nMy only complaint with this game is that it may crash every once in a while, mods or not, because Bethesda games usually crash a whole bunch for no specific reason. Sure, you can have 8+ hour sessions where the game will run smooth and not crash whatsoever or you can be playing for about an hour and have it crash when you enter an interior. In my opinion, the game is badly optimized but that's the only con, and the pros outweight the cons by A LOT.

reviewText:
Arguably the best installment of the Elder Scrolls series (yes, I too love Morrowind dearly but let's be real, many of its systems and all of its visuals are too horrible to endure in this day and age, despite the plot and setting).

The most landscape variation in any TES title, great imaginative sidequests, far more interesting NPCs than the mind-numbing bores of Skyrim. Oblivion gates can get a little boring but nobody's forcing you to really go in all of them.

If only we could get all of this beauty ported to the Skyrim engine one day...

reviewerDisplayName: Kaelan, The Titan God of Doom.
reviewText: The 10th of Evening Star, 3E433, 6am, It was a cold morning, Looking for an adventure the 25 Year old Orc Lord Kaelan Warsong found the Cave know as 'Pillaged Mine' Kaelan walked inside hoping to have some fun. Kaelan walked in and the first thing he sees is a massive Goblin Warlord, A Challenge! He draws his sword raises his shield and readdies himslef for this fight. The fight starts an exchange of blocking and swing on both sides a fair fight, Then something changes a second Warlord comes from deeper in the mine. This fight just got alot harder but still winable. The fight continues Kaelan gets hit from the back! but by what the two Warlords are infront of him! he quickly turns and sees a headless zombie summoned by a Goblin shaman! He worrys maybe this fight is not sided to him anymore. the fight gos on and on for several minutes Kaelan manages to kill both Warlords and the zombie just as he kills the zombie the shaman summons another he kills the next and the next and the next he stops bothering to kill the zombies and runs at the shaman as he gets close the shaman runs deeper into the mine, Kaelan follows. The fight ends up in the second half of the mine Kaelan stops takes a long gasp looks up and sees over ten Goblin Warlords fifteen Goblin Shamans and each shaman summons a headless zombie. Kaelan slowly walks backwords hoping to escape fearing for his life he runs, Once out Pillaged Mine Kaelan looks back at the door and covers it will a bolder and walks away never speeking of this again.\nThe moral of the story is 1 on 1 combat is Oblivion is Amazing, Anything more then a 1 v 3 is ♥♥♥♥ing broken in the enemies favor.\nTrue Story from Gameplay of Kaelan, The Titan God of Doom 2015.

reviewText: This is a great game and probably in my top 10 favorite games list. It's a great story, great visuals, beautiful setting, and great side quests. There are of course some things that are negetive about this game, like the voice acting. Sometimes you come across the same voice with different characters in the game (and I'm not talking about the guards), the combat is a bit clunky, and this game is way to easy. I've completed the whole main quest and all the other quests, like the Mage Guild, Dark Brotherhood, etc. in under 20 hours and not because it's a short game (it's pretty average length) but I completed it fast because it was very easy.

reviewText:
Solid game.  I would not play without some sort of graphics mods.  Starts the downward trend from Morrowind in the number of equipment slots and this continues downwards into Skyrim which has even less.  Leveling system is the same as Morrowind.  They axed a number of skills.  They didn't both to put spears into the game.

As for voice acting... I would rather have had blocks of text to read.  The voice acting is a great addition, but not when seemingly every NPC you come across pulls from a voice actor pool of ~10 people (sic).  In Morrowind, they gave the important NPCs voices and everyone else had text blocks.  At least then you weren't faced with the realization that everyone had the same voice actors for all of the dialogue.

Even with the negatives, which is mostly just nit-picking, 7/10.  I wouldn't play it again, but I enjoyed myself with it while I played it.

reviewText:
What can I say; I loved this game, but after being spoiled by the game-changing, genre-defining phenomenon which is Brink, I feel like playing this is a bit of a step down. It leaves much to be desired.
Where's the intense parkour? The deformed character models? The completely redundant grenades? The dark and edgy storyline? The overwhelming feeling of buyer's remorse and deep sense of depression after small incriments of gameplay?
Oh well, guess I'll have to wait for the long overdue Brink mod for this game, to bring it upto par.
Until that day; 9.6/10
When that day comes; 11.3/10

reviewText: Oblivion is probably feeling a bit forlorn these days, with most of the hardcore crowd sticking to Morrowind and most of everyone else abandoning it for Skyrim. And it's no great mystery why this is the case, but I still think Oblivion is a game that shouldn't be overlooked, with the proper precautions taken.\n\nIt's no secret that Oblivion is an RPG full of problems. The most grievous one in my opinion is the level scaling system, which scales basically everything in the game from dungeon loot and quest rewards to enemy equipment, gradually making the game more tedious as you level up until you finally find yourself face to face with a highway bandit who somehow found a full suit of Daedric armor and you just have to wonder where your decisions went so wrong that led you to this moment. The persuasion system is literally a joke, in which you just play a little wheel minigame where you dish out your best knock knock jokes (or boasts, if they're into that) until they have no choice but to tell you everything they know so that you'll leave them alone. I still don't know what the Speech stat even does, because as far as I'm aware you can start working on your standup routine fresh out of prison and never suffer any penalty. There's very little feeling of character specialization, and there's no reason at all to not be the leader of every guild in the game, the owner of your own order of knights, and more because even if you want to play the game as a stealthy archer or something the game all but forces you to become a combat focused character where your major choice boils down to magic or hitting things" and there are no guilds that are strictly designed around a certain playstyle
date: making each of them less interesting for the people who did specialize towards one guild. The main storyline in general is fairly boring

hoursPlayed: to the point that I didn't even think that the collective content of it as a whole was as amusing as the single little Sheogorath quest in the base game.\n\nThe good thing is that thanks to the magic of mods

reviewText: When this game first came out, I only was only about 10 or so. I only got to play it every now and then on my brother's xbox. Going back now and really getting into the game, it still holds up. I always had fun with this game back in the day, and it's still incredibly fun. It's a game where 10 years later, you'll still find new things in it. 10 years later, the graphics are a little dated, but not horribly ancient. However, the story and the soundtrack more than make up for the now-dated graphics. This game is one of my all-time favorite video game soundtracks. God bless Jeremy Soule.

reviewText: This is by far my favorite Elder Scrolls game. I owned the hard copy previously and when I saw it on Steam I knew I had to get it. The environment in this Elder Scrolls is the best out of all the games. Tamriel has a peaceful air to it filled with vibrant color and good amounts of green. The story is easy to follow and maintains interest. All of the side quests and other distractions give this game 1000's of hours of gameplay potential.\n\nThe only complaint I have about this game is the leveling system. The level of enemies is based on your level so if you focus too much on levelling non-combat skills, the enemies become very tough to kill. This is more then made up for by the rest of the game though, so I'd still give a 10/10. Shadow guide you.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The game that defined the modern RPG and arguably the best game ever written.

In the two years since escaping from the Imperial prison I have become a holy crusader, a gladiator in the arena, fallen from grace, spent an uncomfortable two weeks as a vampire, defeated at least one ancient evil, driven ghosts out of my home and been made into a god.

Also, there's some problem in Kvatch, which people keep on referring to as the 'main quest'.

Massive, I'm nearly 200 hours in and there are parts of the main game and bits of DLC I haven't even started to look at. With the 'unofficial' patches from the community this game has had most of it's bugs fixed and runs well on modern PCs. Other community mods make it an incredibly pretty game, fix gameplay issues and add oodles more content.

Look at http://www.nexusmods.com/oblivion for mods and patches.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Hallelujah Holy ♥♥♥♥.

This game is amazing. Of all of the modern Elder Scrolls games (Morrowind, Oblivion, Skyrim, ES: Online), this is, in my opinion, the best. It lacks some of Skrim's refinement. But my God, this game is beautiful in every way. It has an amazing, lovingly constructed world that you can tell that Bethesda cares about. The Music is outstanding. The main story line is well written and unravels itself beautifully.
TL;DR: Buy it. Right Now.
10/10. Would quest again.

reviewText: All in all, I find this game way more appeling than its more modern counter-part, Skyrim. In my opinion the guilds are a lot more immersive and in-depth as you work your way up the chain in a way that makes sense for that particular group; battling evil necromancers and getting recommendations for the arcane university, rather than Skyrim's cast a simple spell get into the arcane college. The main story is also pretty epic, as the invasion of the daedra draws near ever minute, you along with the local Blades need to take certain actions to stop this onslaught. Need a break from quests or need something else to do in the game? Well you can make your own adventures by clearing the local fort or dungeon, either by yourself or with a group of adept adventures behind your back. The only issues I came across dealt with the leveling up/character build mechanic. Cookie-cutter characters are hard to make as a wizard build has to be purely towards the most magicka to cast the higher tier spells; warrior builds and theif builds aren't as restricting, but are still a little rigid. Also at a certain point your character becomes too good"
date: as your attributes hit insane heights. You become really hard to kill
recommended: save for a room FILLED with top quality enemies or a named legendary enemy. I'll admit that the perk system of Skyrim is better
hoursPlayed: as it rewards using skills and allows for intresting characters to form. Would give this game around a 9.5/10. The DLC's are amazing btw."

reviewText: You know, Bethesda doesn't exactly make really excellent games... you buy their stuff because they're the ONLY high-profile developer out there that makes their particular variety of open-world RPG. In a Bethesda game, you can go anywhere on the (typically) VERY large world map, and do just about anything you in-game character in capable of doing at anytime you please. That level of freedom to do whatever the **** you want goes a long way.\n\nSO, while Oblivion has a whole list of stupid/annoying mistakes and flaws, it's still worth playing through a few times or more. There's just SO MUCH you can do with it, especially if you start modding, which can really make this game shine.

reviewText: If you don't have this game, or if you have never played this game, then you are missing out on one of the best open world games that has ever been created. The map is huge, the art style and the different environments are beautiful, and there are tons of quests to distract you from the main story. There are different guilds you can join that can appeal to different tastes. Honestly, the only main problem that I have with this game, other than a few small glitches, is the Oblivion gates. They're fun at first, but they can get a little repetitive. Still, this game is one of my top 5 favorite games of all time. 9/10

reviewText: After playing many hours of this game on my ps3 I decided to also pick up the PC edition for the add-ons and mods. This game has yet to fail to wow me in terms of scope and design. Sure the world may feel empty and your actions inconsequential, but it doesn't really bug me. I think it's pretty sweet that  I can be the listener for the dark brotherhood at night and be a holy crusader by day. The levelling system, though in many ways worse than Skyrim's, reminds me of an old-school style hard core RPG in terms of the skills and attributes. All in all, you would do well to pick up this game and give it a go.

reviewText: Oblivion is one of my favourite games ever.  It has so much to do in the game: there are loads of quests, tons of weapons and Armour, lots of skills and immersive RPG elements.  I have spent many hours playing this game and I have still to experience all that oblivion has to offer.  It may be an old game with lacklustre graphics but I do not believe that graphics makes a game instead you should not look at the age of the game and should instead look at the vast amounts of game play it has to offer.\nThere are also tons of mods you can get for the game.  These range from weapons, Armour and items to houses, quests, graphical enhancements and even game play changes.  You can find all of these mods on nexusmods.com.\nOverall, this game has a lot of game play elements, fun and mods that makes this game one of the greatest ever made.  I strongly recommend this game even if you are not fond of RPG’s.

reviewText:
Played this game for hundeds of hours on console recently got it on steam. Oblivion has always been my favourite game in The Elder Scrolls series and perhaps in my top 5 ever.

The open world of Tamriel's central province Cyrodil is stunningly georgeous for a game made in 2005 and remains iconic to this day. The story is in my opinion the best the series has ever produced and this game is easily home to the best DLC from and Elder Scrolls game, The Shivering Isles.

Oblivion unlike its younger brother Skyrim (Also a great game) Isn't easily mastered and does present a challenge at higher levels, Yes you get god like strong and epicly awsome equipment ans spells but so do your enemies. And the best enchantments on weapons eat up your soul gems.

Oblivions class system is somethinng I missed in Skyrim, It makes you focus and develop your Character along the 7 skills you chose though you still can master all skills though any skill you did not chose as a major skill doesn't level you up.

The combat at levels 15+ clearly rises in difficulty. Enemies start staggering you in close quarters and you sniping skills need to improve fast along with adding some poisons and preferably an enchantment on your bow to keep getting those one shot kills.

I could write a novel on the game but in short Oblivion is an excelent open world rpg with a great story fun characters and factions and always gives you something to do

10/10 if you havent played this get it asap
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: While I don't like the way Bethesda is making their games easier and dumbing down their content, this game is still enjoyable.  I'd rather they didn't remove so many skill lines, or remove negative consequences. You can do it all in this game, you aren't forced to choose right vs wrong, nor is there any real depth to the characters. You can kill anyone you want without consequences. The point of a Role Playing game is your actions should result in game changing events, there is way too much hand-holding going on. This is more like an FPS in a Elder Scrolls setting.

reviewText:
I've actually owned this a loooooong time ago for the Xbox 360, but I liked it so much I bought it again. That and the mods.

This game truly brings back memories of taking turns with my dad playing it and how bad we were at fighting in the Arena.

Or the time when we beat up a bandit in full Ebony regailia, stole it, and wore it for the rest of the game.
(which is sort of why part of my screen name is Ebon.)

My Good" Opinions:

Feels very adventure-y/immersive
date:
good to sink a couple hours into.
Colorful and varied landscapes.
Towns were filled with quests and cool characters.
The player wasn't the BIG DEAL protagonist through the main campaign
recommended:
but a very vital component to the campaign.
Lots of different stats and class mixing.
Major DLCs were fun and added more stuff to play with. (Plus Sheogorath is always a good reason to buy an expansion.)
Can leave you with fond memories.
The guilds were fun (even though the Mage's and the Fighter's Guild quests were a little bit boring.)
Mods!

My "Bad" Opinions:

Buggy (it's a Bethesda game
hoursPlayed:
what'd I expect?).
Lack in variation to voice actors (also not a big suprise).
Oblivion gates were boring and really had not much variety.
Patrick Stewart never got to actually voice anything outside our beloved dead emperor.
Dungeon delving gets boring after a while.
So does repetitive quest goals.
Persuasion is useless if I can just pay them cash to give me information.
Vampirism is awful.

Overall:
It's a really good game that leaves you having a satisfying experience.

9/10."

reviewText:
Personally, I would say Oblivion is one of my favorite games I've ever played. Sure, it might be a little old and it might not look as good as Skyrim, but honestly the game makes up for it in content. Plus if it bothers you that much, there are some good mods out there to fix that. I would say that no game I have ever played has ever given me quite the same experience. I don't want to spoil anything but I've owned the game on Xbox and loved it enough to buy it again.

Oblivion has a huge world to explore full of ruins, dungeons, towns and castles. The main questline is amazing but to be honest, I loved the DLCs and guilds more than anything. Oblivion is a very detailed world that you can really get into. I've spent hours just doing side quests and admiring Cyrodiil.

I would absolutely recommend this game to anyone who likes open world games. If you can get this on sale it's even better. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
I am not so good at the whole review thing but here is my review on The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion® Game of the Year Edition!

I don't know what it is about Oblivion that makes me keep coming back for more. It was the third Elder Scrolls that I ever played, and personally my favorite. Everything in this game was perfect. I could have played Skyrim with ease if it had everything that made Oblivion what it is. Skyrim, in my opinion, lacked something. Maybe it was the setting. Maybe it was the story. Maybe it was the higher sense of exploration and less emphasis on slashing your way through enemies. Maybe it was the breathtaking soundtrack. Here is my pros and cons list of this game and my final verdict.

Pros: Masterful story, great combat although bow can be a pain sometimes, side quests that will keep you hooked for hundreds upon hundreds of hours, memorable characters, I could literally get so caught up in seeing what certain npc's would be doing and seeing how there everyday lives unfolded one time i remembered seeing Penniless Olvus dead next to the poor guy were a few guards my best guess of what happened to him is that since he begs he might not have been getting enough to live and tried his hand at pickpocketing someone and got caught because i saw a good amount of gold on his corpse.

Cons: Bow combat can be annoying if you did not mean to pull it back because there is no way to retract it, potato faces which you can easily overlook, and not many voice actors but can also be overlooked seeing as how the quests are great.

The point is, is that this game brings endless possibilities for you to experience and how you play the game is up to you. Will you be a great hero who fights off the mythic dawn and puts a stop to corruption, or will you be a crazy bloodthirsty serial killer who teases the guard egging them on to catch you, perhaps even becoming a adverage citizen earning money off of game, errands, and or investing in shops. The choice is yours, but i can what I can tell you is that you can not pass up on playing this game it is just such a well thought out game, I myself have put in over 1k hours on this game on console, steam, and pc disc combined. If you have not got this already go and get it now, trust me you will not regret it! Final result 5/5 WILL PLAY AGAIN!
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game did plenty of things right, and plenty of things wrong. The quests and story are done beautifully. The voice acting is fantastic. The graphics were excellent for the time, and they are still decent to this day, but only when maxed out and with mods. There is plenty for you to do in this game, and plenty of locations to explore. With all the content, I can see why people put hundreds of hours into this game.

However, I found myself getting bored very quickly with the combat. For a game that is intended to be played for many, many hours, you would expect the combat to remain exciting and not become stale. That's not the case with Oblivion. Swing your sword, block, swing, dodge, swing, block, fireball. That's all there is to it and it gets tedious very quickly. It's just very simple combat.

The leveling system is broken. You can spam spells on yourself and level up your skills like cake. It's very easy to exploit the system, so the urge to do it will be there. Some skills level up too fast and some don't level up fast enough. I ended up using console commands and maxing out my skills and my level just so I wouldn't have to deal with it. I feel like this game doesn't even need a leveling system at all.

Glitches. This game is very glitchy. You will find glitches all the time. You cannot escape the glitches.

This game is much better with mods. Be sure to download plenty of mods.

Even with all my negative talk, I still had some fun playing this game. Maybe you'll enjoy it even more than I did.

reviewText: This is an archetype for free-roaming fantasy RPGs with classic elements of dungeon delving and a consistent leveling mechanism. The game by itself is solid but aged, and it is recommended to install at least the Unofficial mods that fix a lot of bugs. If you want to further improve the game there are tons of mods, but the resulting configuration may be too heavy and/or crash-prone.\nThumbs up for the complete freedom of doing almost everything you want.

Genre: Action Role-Playing[en.wikipedia.org]

GameplayThe Elder Scrolls franchise has a special place in many gamer's hearts, whether they remember a game from the modern trillogy, or the first two games released in the 90's. Whatever the case may be, The Elder Scrolls has always been praised for it's hybrid gameplay style. Blending the interesting aspect of role-playing with the fast paced nature of action games, Oblivion definitely achieves something unique. Bethesda games are almost like a precursor to the modern RPG experience. While using RPG mechanics to develop the storyline, Bethesda presents it with the classic action/FPS style that everyone adores. Thrown into the region of Cyrodiil, the player sets out to fufill whatever he/she desires. The player has the choice to completely skip the main questlines to perhaps favor the smaller quests or areas. The player also has the choice to do no quests, and to just explore the land projected before them. I think the feeling of freedom Oblivion provides is the ultimate factor that generates a replayable game. Most people will start and finish the game in the traditional way, following the main storyline and decision path until the end. But after their first playthrough, players will often go back to see what Cyrodiil holds in content. This decision is heavily rewarded with 5 different factions to join, 21 different skills to utilise, over 112 weapons to equip, over 31 pieces of armor to equip, 8 different houses to own, 9 cities to explore, and a map over 16 square miles in size!

GraphicsThere isn't any reason to cherish Oblivion for it's graphics now, but in 2006, they were considered quite good. However, the blurry textures, low polygon count models, bad lighting, bad animations, and awful meshes can be fixed by a plethora of mods. As far as the settings go for graphics, they are quite good. Oblivion allows you to change pretty much everything about the game except for FOV. There will also be a few things you will want to install before playing though, such as a small mod[www.nexusmods.com] that fixes a small FPS stutter that most players experience. Please don't consider the graphical fidelity of this game before purchasing, as it can be completely changed by free mods.

StoryOblivion features one of my most favorite stories of all time. You begin as a prisoner, forgetful of the reason why you became one in the first place. But by perfect execution of Deus Ex Machina[en.wikipedia.org], the player is immediately free of prison, and tasked with supreme responsibility. Now comes the part of the story that Oblivion really got right. The fact that the player has obtained this supreme task does not phase any NPC until the player makes a good impression on them. This idea is such a relieving sign of a true RPG, as many RPG"s nowadays provide almost no sense of progression as far as character interaction goes. Not only are you graced with the oppertunity of participating in the main quest

reviewText: As someone who almost spend 100h on this game, I can seriously say that to the elder scrolls series, this game is the mario 3 to the super mario games. A formula that works and is fun, but it's just better and a more refined game. I certaintly think Skyrim has made even more improvements to the franchise, but it'll still never catch the charm this game delivered. The epicly crafted open world of Cyrodiil is open, cozy, natural and rural, the way I like it. Dungeons and its loot aren't as unique as Skyrim, yet they still offer great fun. Great story, but I think no one can argue about that, in specific with the dark brotherhood. Character creation isn't perfect, but it's more open than SKyrim, music's top notch and for a 2006 game; it's graphics are great and detailed. So buy it and have yourself an immerive journey through one of the best RPG-games of the 21st century, it's worth every single penny!

Besides Arena, this is my least favorite Elder Scrolls game, The graphics for the environments are nice but the NPCs are ugly as sin, the attempts at immersion are shoddy at best, and the minigames are annoying and rather idiotic.

reviewText:
have you ever played skyrim and think to yourself that magic isint broken enough. if so then this game is for you.

with enchanting you can say i dont need sneak skill and make 100% invisibility armor.

in oblivion you can say who needs lockpicking and use a spell to open locks that is 100% effective.

did you ever end up overweight in the middle of a cave in skyrim. in this game you can make your own ease burden spell and carry up to 500 extra weight.

have you ever thought that alchemy was not broken enough in skyrim. in this game with just a carrot and an apple and a high level you can make over 100 gold potions and you can make them from anywhere.

i mentioned it before but i was so sad when they didnt give me the ability to create my own spells in skyrim. i hope they add it again in the next game.

and the best part is that you dont even need a free hand to cast spells in oblivion. i love having a two handed weapon out in this game and not even have to take it out of my hand to cast things. i also miss the spell wheel with the D pad instead of the list system they have now in skyrim.

dont get me wrong though i loved skyrim i just dont like some of the things they did to magic in the game.

also sorry if the english is off. i rate this game 10/10

reviewText:
Decided to re-write my review seeing as my original review was pretty basic and was written almost three years ago (in 10 days time at the time of writing) There is a TL;DR at the end with summarises the pros and cons of the game.

So, The Elder Scrolls: IV Oblivion starts out you creating your character inside a prison cell, which in Elder Scrolls games has almost become a tradition. You are able to choose between any of the races in the previous installment: Morrowind. Character creation is good, you're given the option to choose your race, gender, looks, hair, hair colour and eye colour among other things. After that you take control of your character inside the Imperial City Prision where in the cell across from you, a Dunmer will give a brief paragraph or two depending on your race. I would almost call him racist seeing as how the only race he 'likes' are fellow Dunmer. After that the Emperor, Uriel Septim VII,
Who is voiced by Patrick Stewart is brung to your cell as there is a secret route out of the City which is in your cell. You tag along with the Emperor and his body guards through this passage as you are attacked by assasins who are part of a Daedric cult called the Mythic Dawn who have assassinated all of the heirs and Uriel is next. Eventually Uriel, and two of his body guards are slain, and you are given the Amulet of Kings and are told to stop Mehrunes Dagon from entering Cryodiil. You exit through the sewers and once that's done you are free do to as you please.

You can do a multitude of things after the tutorial, wether it's join the Arena in the Imperial City as a combatant, Join up with the Mage's or Fighter's guild, join the Dark brotherhood etc.
The plot begins with you taking the Amulet of Kings to the city of Chorrol and finding the head of the blades, then you must visit the destroyed City of Kvatch and find Martin who is unknowingly the illegimate child of Uriel Septim and as such, is the last surviving heir. The plot then focuses around stopping the Daedra invading Cyrodiil and crowning Martin as the Emporer. Eventually Mehrunes Dagon mangages to get into Cyrodiil and Martin must sacrifce himself to force him out and seal the bound between Oblivion and Nirn.

Side quests are fun and intresting, often yeilding gold and unique items as rewards as is the same of the faction quests. The Dark Brotherhood has my favorite quest in the entire game, and probably the entire series, in which you enter a house filled with people who believe there is a chest full of gold somewhere in the house, There are multiple ways of killing them all and the best one is gradually convincing people to split up and then silently disposing of them, until you and two others remain, you can convice them to turn on eachother, and then you can kill off the survivor. Doing this will even earn you a bonus.

Pros
+Large open world, free to do whatever you want
+Quests are intresting and are unique
+Able to enchant your weapons, armour, clothing etc.
+Able to make your own spells
+Lots of dungeons and Oblivion Gates to explore
+NPC's feel alive and react to your presence as the Hero of Kvatch
+Mods, which fix most if not all the problems
+Game looks great, even if it is 10 years old.
+Shivering Isles DLC is amazing.

Cons
-Monsters and NPC's are leveled meaning that certian items are impossible to acquire at lower levels and that there aren't any 'easy' fights
-NPC's have potato's for faces, but mods can fix this.
-Unique items are leveled but they don't scale, meaning if you get an enchanted sword at level 5, it won't scale the damage and enchantments with you, meaning soon it will be useless. Again mods fix this.
-Horse Armour DLC (In no way shape or form necessary)

TL;DR Quests are intresting and fun, there's much to do, Shivering Isles is great, mods fix like 99% of the game's problems, Good RPG elements like atributes, Major and Minor skills. NPC's aren't the greatest, Horse Armour DLC exists, game still looks good today. Replay value is amazing. I could go on but I won't

Easily 10/10, so much better than Skyrim

reviewText: A flawed and aged adventure in Cyrodiil, but incredibly soulful\nThe questlines are lenthy and engaging. The scenery is awe inspiring. The character models and mechanics, however, haven't aged well. Combat in particular feels like a step in the right direction, but still far from satisfying. Yet, whatever flaws Oblivion has are easily fixed thanks to the extensive modding community. While Cyrodiil isn't quite as insteresting of a setting as Morrowind, it possesses a certain depth and character that Skyrim failed to live up to.

reviewText: Amazing combat system, amazing atmosphere, takes you into a glimpse of the good and bad, poor and rich. The cyrodilic land of one of my favorite race's: The Imperial's. The heartland inhabitant's of the empire. This game will take you into a literal RPG and will give you shiver's from walking into a dungeon, a heartwarming welcome when you enter a town and be approached by your fellow friend's you meet on you journey's. I've logged in 1000's of hours into this game, read every book, did every quest, had every item, enchanted with all possible enchantment's, and casted every spell. Every town has a diversity, you'll want to go to the one's you're most welcome at. Every character has a specialty, you'll want to focus on your favorite's and never regret it.\n10/10 Even when compared to its better-half, Morrowind.\n

reviewText: A flawed and aged adventure in Cyrodiil, but incredibly soulful\nThe questlines are lenthy and engaging. The scenery is awe inspiring. The character models and mechanics, however, haven't aged well. Combat in particular feels like a step in the right direction, but still far from satisfying. Yet, whatever flaws Oblivion has are easily fixed thanks to the extensive modding community. While Cyrodiil isn't quite as insteresting of a setting as Morrowind, it possesses a certain depth and character that Skyrim failed to live up to.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion, is an epic game. There is flaws however, like that really stupid speech minigame, and the NPCs not showing any emotions when they talk to each other. But besides those and a few other issues, its an excellent game! The world is so open to you, and Cyrodiil is so beautiful. I did not really like the main story and the fighters guild  quests that much, but I loved the Dark Brotherhood quests and the Thieves Guild quests. Overall, i give it a solid 9/10. If you have not played it, shame on you!

~ R.O.B The Robot

reviewText: I have played Oblivion for about 80+ hours, completed The Shivering Isles and the main questline. I still haven't gotten around to completing EVERY quest in the game, but I got most of it.\n\nIn Oblivion, you start out in a prison cell after a small monologue and character creator. An NPC mocks your choice of race and then the emporer himself comes to your cell. The Septim line is being attacked by an unknown force, and he is escaping the city to survive. Destiny destiny destiny, tutorial, class picking, bla bla bla... and then you finally are put into the world. When you first step out, you'll either say one of two things: Wow! This is amazing!" Or: "Wow! These graphics suck!" Oblivion is a dated classic

reviewText:
While I have only played mere hours of this game on PC I have played days and weeks on consoles.  I had this game on release of the PS3, after waiting months after its release on Xbox.  I had to have it.  It revolutionised the gaming world for me.

Oblivion has perhaps the most in depth questline of any game I have ever played, by questline I include the side quests in the world.  There is something for anyone in this game.

There are many faults to this game, graphics, gameplay, voice acting (not the main characters for these are done superbly by Ian McKellen, Sean Bean and Terence Stamp).  But it is a world begging for adventure.

If you like stories of questing and heroes then this is for you.

A gem among RPGs.
