reviewText:
For me, this is the best game in the series. Only thinking about it makes me lyrical. The stretching fields, the daunting forests, the authentic towns, the epic storyline, the sidequests that are equally amazing. For me, literally the only negative point in this game are the faces generated by the engine. I've lost hours and hours on this game, in three different versions. If you are a fan of fantasy epics, go for it. If you like to start a game to just go berserk and kill things, go for it. If you're a statistics kinda guy, who would like every minor detail to matter, I would recommend Morrowind more, but I'd still say go for it.
No matter what you like, you'll probably lose days in this game. Plus, the immense library of mods existing for it make the game stretch long past its expiration date, with premium graphics mods, great separate questlines, followers, and other great stuff.

Buy it. Just buy it, and never regret it.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is the epitomy of the fantasy genre. It has perfect mechanics for getting into RPGs without being too streamlined or confusing. The environment is perfectly put together and will keep you invested for months at a time. The levelling is set up so that the game can actually get harder as you play, instead of easier and boring like another game in the series. This is the perfect game to play as a first RPG, and it will keep veterans just as entertained. This game is far over-shadowed by its comparatively mediocre sequel, and I highly recommend everyone to play this game and some of its predeccessors for an idea of what a true open-world fantasy experience should be.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Oblivion I feel is the weakest compared to Morrowind and Skyrim. It lacks the refinement of Skyrim in combat and radiant AI as well as Morrowind depth and quest connectivity. Nevertheless, I always enjoyed Oblivion quite a lot as it was my first TES game and the one the modded most heavily. While it can be quite bland in some places, I could always look past that but it could put off quite a few people. Then there are the mods. Personally, I always found that, at least for the moment, Oblivion mods are the easiest to find and most plentiful out of the TES games. Most MW mods seem scatter across various sites while the big Skyrim mods are still in deveiopement. Overall, I would say that it is still a pretty good game that definately is worth it.

reviewText:
While I have only played mere hours of this game on PC I have played days and weeks on consoles.  I had this game on release of the PS3, after waiting months after its release on Xbox.  I had to have it.  It revolutionised the gaming world for me.

Oblivion has perhaps the most in depth questline of any game I have ever played, by questline I include the side quests in the world.  There is something for anyone in this game.

There are many faults to this game, graphics, gameplay, voice acting (not the main characters for these are done superbly by Ian McKellen, Sean Bean and Terence Stamp).  But it is a world begging for adventure.

If you like stories of questing and heroes then this is for you.

A gem among RPGs.

reviewText: I have played Oblivion for about 80+ hours, completed The Shivering Isles and the main questline. I still haven't gotten around to completing EVERY quest in the game, but I got most of it.\n\nIn Oblivion, you start out in a prison cell after a small monologue and character creator. An NPC mocks your choice of race and then the emporer himself comes to your cell. The Septim line is being attacked by an unknown force, and he is escaping the city to survive. Destiny destiny destiny, tutorial, class picking, bla bla bla... and then you finally are put into the world. When you first step out, you'll either say one of two things: Wow! This is amazing!" Or: "Wow! These graphics suck!" Oblivion is a dated classic

reviewText: Oblivion I feel is the weakest compared to Morrowind and Skyrim. It lacks the refinement of Skyrim in combat and radiant AI as well as Morrowind depth and quest connectivity. Nevertheless, I always enjoyed Oblivion quite a lot as it was my first TES game and the one the modded most heavily. While it can be quite bland in some places, I could always look past that but it could put off quite a few people. Then there are the mods. Personally, I always found that, at least for the moment, Oblivion mods are the easiest to find and most plentiful out of the TES games. Most MW mods seem scatter across various sites while the big Skyrim mods are still in deveiopement. Overall, I would say that it is still a pretty good game that definately is worth it.

reviewText:
Oblivion: it feels like a parody of Skyrim.

Not only are Skyrim's graphics better, but the world itself just feels more serious and realistic than its predecessor. The game is sort of a more relaxed Skyrim, that was my first impression.

But nonetheless, I can guarantee you that I had more fun with Oblivion! There are few games that made me laugh so hard. But don't think that Oblivion is all about laughing. The game is filled with very entertaining and well made side quests that feel as if they aren't side quests, but the main story itself. I actually did not play much the main story, just because the side quests were so good!

The graphics? Nothing special nowadays, but definately playable!  The game is just so good, that you will probably get more immersed than in Skyrim, even with the simpler graphics. Hours will fly by and you won't notice. I guess that the graphics also helped create more complex environments. The cities in Oblivion are much bigger than the ones in Skyrim. There are endless hours of fun in the cities, from messing around with the guards to exploring sewers and doing quests. It just feels more complex than Skyrim!

Don't get me wrong, both are excellent games, but have slight different approaches. Skyrim is a masterpiece of beauty and thrilling adventure, while Oblivion focuses on the complexity and fun of its world.

My suggestion? Buy both!

(Don't trust Steam hour record! I have endless hours of offline play in both games!)

reviewText:
There's a big chance that you're looking at Oblivion because you played Skyrim and wanted to check the other Elder Scrolls games. This review is mainly going to be a comparison between the 2.

Main story of Oblivion revolves around Martin Septim, the last remaining son of the emperor. He has to deal with Mehrunes Dagon, daedric prince who starts to open portals across Cyrodiil. You play as the Hero of Kvatch and help Martin by fetching him some important items and defeating a not so strong boss.

Quests:
There are no quest arrows in Oblivion. Markers are present on the compass.

Quests themselves, at least a lot of them, just like in Skyrim, require dungeon crawling. The entire Fighters Guild questline is pretty much just this.

Leveling:
Leveling is quite different in Oblivion. At the start of the game, you choose your major skills. Training them allows you to level up. The minor skills can be trained as well though. In order to successfully level up and be able to choose which attributes to give points to, you have to sleep.

Combat:
Combat in Oblivion is a lot clunkier than in Skyrim. Also some enemies can make you fall and that is not fun to fight against, even though they barely scratch your health.

Weapons and armor in Oblivion also have health. The more damaged they get, the less effective they are. In order to repair them, you need to buy or find repair hammers.

You cannot fight while on a horse, but at least you have a first person camera.

Alchemy:
In Oblivion you don't need Alchemy stations, but you will need to find at least a mortar and a pestle, an item which lets you mix potions wherever you want, as long as there are no enemies nearby. Like in Skyrim, you can sample raw ingredients and level up your alchemy skill.

Spells:
Spells in Oblivion come from the schools that are in Skyrim plus the Mysticism school. If you are a Mage's Guild member and have access to the Arcane University you will be able to create your own spells. The more powerful the spell is, the more gold will be required.

Enchanting is present as well. Enchanted items can be created from the sigil stones found in the Oblivion gates and the Altar of Enchanting found at the Arcane University. You can put as much effects as you want at an altar, but it will cost gold.

Graphics:
Obviously, Skyrim has the better graphics, but Oblivion can be modded as well, with overhauls and stuff.

Overall, to me, Oblivion is an older Skyrim with different quests. The differences are not that big.

reviewText:
It is a great game. So far I have around 40 hours on it and I have completed the main quest, thieves guild, dark brotherhood, arena, mages guild and almost the shivering isles. The review will be in 6 sections- graphics, combat/magic, guilds, dlc, main quest, overall.

Graphics:
Obviously due to its age oblivion is not looking great but it has aged quite well and the graphics does not change the fact that it is a great game. Also this can be touched up with mods.

Combat/Magic:
The combat is not great and not particularly enjoyable. I therefore enchanted my self an OP bow early that does a ton of damage spread over a large radius(it one hits pretty much everything in a certain radius from the guy that was hit with the arrow). However I like the fact that you can cast spells whilst having other weapons equipped unlike in skyrim.

Guilds:
This will be an oblivion to skyrim comparison
thieves guild is better in oblivion- you steal more, get better rewards and it is less of the dungeon crawling.
dark brotherhood I would say is equal. In oblivion it is long but entertaining whereas skyrim it is short but sweet
mages guild is better thsn the college of winterhold. The recommendations can be tedious but the rest is a lot better.
fighters guild is do not know about as I have not done it.
Arena is better than the s**t bards college

DLC:
This will be a skyrim to oblivion comparison
Oblivion has a lot of useless dlc that pretty much equals hearthfire so i will only be talking about Knights of the nine, dawnguard, shivering isles and dragonborn.
Shivering Isles is amazing and the best part of oblivion. It at the very least equals dragonborn another amazing dlc.
Knights of the nine looks great whereas I did not much like dawnguard.

Main Quest:
Oblivion main story was a better plot the skyrim and felt more important. However the oblivion gates mechanic and the dragons both got boring. I enjoyed playing through both of them a lot and to be honest if you enjoyed either of them you will like the other.

Overall: If you like skyrim do not be afraid to try oblivion. It might be tough to get used to but it is definitely on par with skyrim and if produced tomorrow would probably be a better game.

reviewText:
TL;DR Without mods good, with mods great

There are several reasons to only briefly review the vanilla game. One, it's now almost a decade old, and hasn't aged particularly well. Frequent bugs, butt-ugly character models, and crashes (especially on newer systems) abound. Two, vanilla reviews have been done to death, and there's no reason to just talk about experiences everyone else has had. Three, I'm only doing this review to show off to my friends my excellent choice in mods.

That being said, the vanilla game was legit. I did my best to overlook the rough edges, and the game turned out to be pretty fun. Charles was the most powerful darkmage (custom class ftw) in all the land, and that was before I discovered the +100% Chameleon spell trick. Despite a much more varied and exciting Dark Brotherhood questline and the ability to create custom spells, though, unmodded Oblivion didn't hold a candle to unmodded Skyrim. In Oblivion, the daedric lord quests, Mages guild and Thieves guild rising-through-the-ranks quests, and oblivion gates (Skyrim dragon fight parallels) were boring and repetitive. Shivering Isles was fun, and had some cool weapons and characters, but paled in comparison to Skyrim's DLC quests. Don't get me wrong, Oblivion was a fun experience. However, if it wasn't moddable, I'd probably go back to Skyrim.

But it is moddable. And I'm still going strong at 120+ hours. Now for the mods I use. darkness, this is where you'll start caring. Bear in mind that 1. I may not spell it right, cause my filing system is wacky and 2. I haven't included any armor or clothing mods cause frankly I don't care.

I ended up having to install a bunch of mods like obmm, obse, menuQue, and nifse. Still, most mods either require one of these, or at the very least are made easier to install with one. But, of the actual game-content-changing mods, these were the cream of the crop in no real order.

DarNified UI
Makes the UI for menus and inventories much more compact, and makes them less irritating to scroll through. Essential for hoarders.

Midas Magic Spells of Aurum
Doesn't really change the existing spells, but adds 200+ magic spells to the game, about 30 of which are actually cool. The quests to find the recipes was long, and only rarely felt like I was slogging through a pit of tar for no reason.

Deadly Reflex v6/Unnecessary Violence III
Both overhaul the combat system, making it more realistic, challenging, and fun. Personally I prefer UV3, but I used DR for a while and it was okay. I recommend UV3, though, if only because of the many combat moves it adds.

Golden Crest
A pirate/fight club/bounty hunter mod. Adds pirates, a fight club, and a bounty hunter guild. Really irritating at times, and the custom music made my ears bleed, but the sheer amount of content was mind boggling. Just be prepared to read a lot of things, really fast.

Sneak Multiplier Change
Changes the max stealth attack bonuses from x3 and x6 to x7 and x15. Though the x7 multiplier rarely works for bows, the mod still makes being stealthy far more rewarding.

Ranokoas City Stealth Exits
Adds hidden ways to get into each city, so those of us with large bounties can more easily avoid the psychic guards.

Conduit Magic
Allows you to enchant a weapon with any spell you cast, and then have attacks with that weapon drain your magicka instead of soul gems. Super awesome, especially if you have high magicka.

The Forgotten Realm
The very best dungeon mod I've ever played. Made me feel like a true adventurer, more than anything else in Oblivion had so far. A fitting adjective for the mod would be Sprawling". Just be sure to bring plenty of torches.

Laser Gun-Attack of the Droids
The "quest" you can do is really lame
date:
but the weapons you can get are really awesome.

Adsense Epic Dungeon
Another great dungeon mod. Shorter than the Forgotten Realm
recommended: and with a little too much backtracking for my liking
hoursPlayed:
but still a lot fun.

The Secrets Mod
It adds secrets. So far
voteText:
I've found only one.

Oblivion XP and Elys' Uncapper
These two together make the process of leveling up more intuitive than in the vanilla game. Plus
helpfulPercent: if you have an already-created character
votesHelpful:
the mod gives you a chance to completely redo your attribute and skill points.

Werewolf V2
Never played v1
votesTotal:
but the mounds of shiny loot you acquire throughout the quest are worth the short playtime. Had some fairly good voice acting as well.

Alternative Start V1

reviewText: If you are an Elder Scrolls fan, you probably have already picked up this game. In case you haven't though, here is why you need to. The Elder Scrolls series has been famous for its magic. The amount of detail spent on different types of spell types and effects is something truely the RPG fan will enjoy. The quests are all very entertaining and fun to do. The melee combat system could be a little less repetitive, but they still provide an entertaining time. It might be hard for the casual gamer to pick up and play, but it is worth the experience. I would give this game a solid 9.8. A few annoying glitches encountered made it a little difficult at times, and the melee combat could be better.

reviewText:
I played The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind before ever playing this game, and I always felt that this game took a step forward from III with graphics, combat, and other mechanics.. but several steps backward with exploration, character-building, and true roleplay.

I'm not reviewing Morrowind here, but I think it is fair to compare a game against its predecessor and look at what was improved and what was taken in the wrong direction.

To begin, Oblivion did a lot of things right, when improving on mechanics compared to Morrowind. We'll start with combat. In Morrowind, your character's skill with your chosen weapon, along with one of your main stats, determined your chance to hit, as a percentage. If the game calculated that chance and determined that you would miss" with that swing

Oblivion took the combat system and made it much more action-oriented and controlled by you

reviewText:
As you can tell from the hours I have put into this game, I have greatly enjoyed every moment of it. Although, some quests can be quite challenging, your friendly and not so friendly community will give you information to help you on your way. That of course, you have to build your points in each level you achieve, such as personality, strength, intelligence and so on.

The not so challenging, but would I say repetitive quest was definitely the 'Finding Your Roots' quest, where I was constantly being told to collect 10, and then 20, and then 30, and lastly 40 Nirnroots, and dreadfully being told I can  collect more Nirnroot for future references. After spending 3 hours on the entire quest, I think I will leave it be for now.

A proud moment for me was when I finally found all the ingredients to cure my Vampirism. Seek that choice at your own cost! But most of all, when you close all the Oblivion gates, that is a great achievement.

The game itself presents a lot of adventure, a huge variety of quests, a lot of places to explore and lots of dangerous species to kill which makes the entire game as a whole, a really great game play.

As part of the Elder Scrolls, I recommend playing this game first out of the series.

reviewText: My first and probably my personal favourite Elder Scrolls game, though I can see why other titles in the series may be considered better. The experience on the 360 was alright, but if you plan on buying it on PC be ready to mod the ♥♥♥♥ out of the game. Some things feel okay for consoles but not so much for the PC like the UI and graphical fidelity, then there are some other quality of life things too you might want. One thing that I found can't quite be fixed with mods is the horrid level scaling. Sure there are a few combat and level scaling overhauls and what not but they're a bit of a pain to install and get working and they tend to either not fix the problem or make it worse by making basic enemies like bandits tough as ♥♥♥♥ from the start. But enough of my rant, either way if you haven't played another Elder Scrolls game you'll probably enjoy this one, but if you have then you will probably want to mod it in some way or another. DEfinitely better than Skyrim though, 10/10 GOTYAY

reviewText:
[Full Review of The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion]

Graphics:
This game came out in 2006 so the graphics are obviously going to be dated by this point, but if you've played Bethesda RPGs before, you already know that the graphics aren't going to be the strongest aspect of the game anyway. Aside from graphical quality, the landscape is bright and beautiful as well as very detailed, considering it's size. Certain towns and locations obviously got more attention than others though and the characters look . . . not . . . good. However this game is huge and features a tremendous amount of content so it gets a slight pass. - 7/10

Audio:
Again, if you've played a Bethesda RPG before (specifically an Elder Scrolls game) you already have a pretty good idea of what to expect. The soundtrack is nothing short of amazing - it always is in Elder Scrolls' games. So, no surprises there - Jeremy Soule is a god amongst men and all that. Sound effects are also good but I wasn't too crazy about the voice acting in this one, though maybe that's just me. Extremely strong audio presentation overall. - 9/10

Gameplay:
It's your standard RPG with a whole mess of choices to make while creating your character including race, class, attributes, ect. There are many options but it ultimately boils down to the basic warrior, mage, and rogue classes - though you can use any style of weapons, armor, and magic regardless of class, which is a mechanic unique to Bethesda I believe. Combat is nothing special but, then again, it hardly ever is in RPGs. Exploration, however, is one of the strongest aspects of Oblivion and what ultimately makes the game as addicting as it is. You will feel like a real adventurer traveling across Cyrodil saving the world, as well as a few NPCs, along the way. - 8/10

Story:
So, basically, you are the chosen one and it's your destiny to save the world. Super original right? But in all seriousness, the main quest line is pretty interesting and I found myself completely invested in the story by the time it was over. In addition to the main quest line there are also several others (Dark Brotherhood, Thieves Guild, Mages Guild, Fighters Guild, ect.) in addition to TONS of other side quests. All in all, there is a lot of story here, most of which is pretty interesting. - 10/10

Replayability:
It's an RPG . . . and it's made by Bethesda. Just those two facts alone should tell you that you are not going to be leaving your computer screen for quite a few days, should you choose to pick this game up. I've personally played hundreds of hours of Oblivion across all platforms and still haven't completed all the quests. Also, there's real incentive to play multiple times since there are numerous races (all with special abilities) and some really fun quests that you'll probably want to replay but not a lot of key decisions to make throughout the game, at least for an RPG. So, yeah, there's replayability here. - 9/10

Overall:
Oblivion wasn't declared GOTY by everyone for no reason. The explorations mechanics, interesting storyline, and immersive universe all come together perfectly to, once again, give us an addicting role-play experience. If you've never played it for some reason, you need to pick up the GOTY edition like, right now. - 8.6/10

reviewText: I went into this game as someone who enjoyed Skyrim and a gamer who is willing to give old games a chance. Obviously Skyrim is one of the greatest games of its time now but at its time Oblivion was still a huge game. The problem with Skyrim was that the world was so massive but it was kind of flat. Bethesda has always been great at building beautiful worlds but not having stories that mattered and just having endless dungeons. This game has a slightly better story but not by much. It still follows the same ideas of the different groups like the mages, warriors, assassins, and thieves along with all the other quests along the way. Still, its a wonderful game and if you enjoyed Skyrim you'll enjoy this game too. My only critique is not having companions at all and I don't care for games that just create creatures to to match your level because it makes leveling up pointless. New monsters aren't better, just given more health and more punch which kinda sucks. I'm also really glad that they made the DLC's free for buying the game and the Shivering Isles DLC is really, really good. My advice to you for this game, if you do the mages guild quests make sure you keep the character Eridor and not finish his quest. He is the closest thing to having a companion in the game and he followed throughout almost the whole game.

reviewText: Let me first start off, being a 13 yr old, this game was the very first Mature rated game that I've ever played. I used to watch my dad play it as a kid and died to play it. I always wondered why my dad told me to leave when he found an oblivion gate xD He finally allowed me to play it when I turned 10. I first played it at my uncle's on his 360 and since I didn't have a 360 at the time, I sucked. But automatically I could tell this game was gonna rank high in my favorite games list. My dad then gave me his disc copy of the game after Skyrim came out. I played this game for hours apon hours and was really jazzed up when skyrim was announced. I couldn't play skyrim at the time but I didn't care. Now, the reason this game is my favorite out of the 5 games (excluding ESO cause that doesn't classify as an elder scrolls game) is because of the beautiful music, gorgeous atmosphere and use of color in the landscape, combat system, voice acting, main quest, side quests, and of course all of the dungeons, caves, forts, alyied ruins, and towns you can visit. I also dedicated a lot of time into using the Construction Set and downloading community mods. It's all a tremendously fun and neverending experience. Oblivion will still be played 10 years from now with the community supporting it. I have 4 different copies of this game of which the steam edition I just bought like an hour ago. I love the game this much that I would write a really long review and buy 4 different copies of it. I couldn't tell you how long I've played this game. Overall the best experience I ever had in a game. Long live the empire! I would become the Champion of Cyrodiil once more, or two, or ten! ~ 200/10

reviewText: No, I mean. No. A game literally can not be this damn good. There's a bias in my opinion of course, having played this game before I played Morrowind and Skyrim, but all things considered, Oblivion is the highlight of the series. With Morrowind you had great variation in the environment and a truly wonderful game. And then came Oblivion, offering many, many, many hours of gameplay [I have 2500+ on PS3] and an incredible replay value. A game is all about how it makes you feel. Oblivion, with it's bright and vivid colours, compelling story, and amazing design makes you feel like you're in the game. I don't want to sound completely biased, so I want to say some negative things about it, which is hard for me. There are [it being a Bethesda game, after all] a fair share of its bugs and glitches. A few quests in the game were scrapped halfway through, and hearing people reference these quests which can't be completed, initaded, or even alluded to more than once are bothersome. The design of caves, forts, and dungeons can get repetitve. Many people complain about the NPC's faces, which, in the reality of things, aren't bad. Some are absolutely revolting [Bruma guards, specifically. And this one guard in Anvil], but the majority are well done. The soundtrack is the best I've ever heard. The music is cheerful, and fits the environment perfectly. [Jeremy Soule has a talent for that, look at KotOR]. The variation in the wilderness and in the cities is delightful. Each city has its own style of architecture, influenced by various cultures from The Elder Scrolls series. Easily my favorite game of all time, no matter what genre you're interested in, give it a try. Put away any preconceived notions of the game's quality based on graphics [which aren't even that bad, especially for 2006] and experience that which is Oblivion.

reviewText:
TESIV: Oblivion is a great game. Many TES fans refer to is as a classic, and I can see why.

Quests in this game are absolutley wonderful. The quests are very interesting, and you can get different outcomes depending on how you play, which makes the game very replayable. There is a lot of different ways to play this game, and you get to choose how you want to play.

The world is huge, and loading screens don't appear when you roam freely. The only time you will get a loading screen is if you enter a dwellin, so you can wonder all around Cyrodil without objections. The game world is enourmous, and with modifications, you can extend it even more. I doubt I will ever filly explore the map in Oblivion.

There is an enormous modding community. Even though there is not a Steam Workshop for Oblivion, installing mods is quick and somple. Modifications are still being developed, even while everyone else is playing Skyrim. Mods range from silly and funny to serious lore to really useful changes. The websites planetelderscrolls.ign.com and nexusmods.com/oblivion are very good resources that I use often.

reviewText:
Every time I load this game up, and the beautiful Cryodill atmosphere renders and the music starts to play, I lose track of everything around me. My girlfriend ceases to matter, stopping to eat becomes a torturous experience, and yesterday I found out that Osama Bin Laden had been killed (not really but you get the point). This game and it's sequel, Skyrim, are a momentous step forward in humanity's quest to become couch-dwelling creatures.
The gameplay is nothing exactly new or innovative, just standard hack-and-slash-and-cast spells, but it is made tolerable and enjoyable when added with the overall package that is Oblivion.
The atmosphere is where this game shines. Set in a medieval European setting with valleys, forests, mountains, swamps, and gates to Hell, this game succeeds at pulling you in completely, with an epic soundtrack to complete it all.
The storyline is adequate and does give you a sense of purspo as you are playing.
All in all a very good game
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: As a long-time Elder Scrolls fan, I must say that this game is truly a masterpiece. I remember when Morrowind came out, how fascinated I was by all of its intricacies. I couldn't believe that a game could feel so alive, that I could be so immersed in a plethora of cultures, ideologies, races and factions all while exploring a beautiful, detailed world and the history that shaped it into what you see it now. It was the stuff epic adventures are made out of.\n\nOblivion takes that core gameplay and expands quite a great deal upon it. The first thing you might notice is the graphical upgrade. Oblivion's graphics were so cutting edge at the time that they still hold up very nicely today. The main story arch is solid, with a well paced build up and a gripping finale. Sidequests, however, are where this game (much like its predecessor) truly shines. There are a lot of side quests, guild quests, artifacts to discover, spells/gear to craft. You will always have something to do, and I find it best to micromanage by assigning priority to your tasks rather than completing quests as you receive them. Thankfully, this game has a much better fast-travel system than Morrowind's, you can click on visited locations on your map to instantly travel there (does take in-game time, so vampires beware!) so back-tracking is manageable. This is a welcome upgrade, as Cyrodiil is a VERY big place. You will also find yourself trekking through the instanced" dungeons and planes of Oblivion quite often. Your adventures through these creature-laden locales will be aided by a very good quest compass
date: use it!\n\nThe expansions are quite good too
recommended: Shivering Isles adds Sheogorath's realm to the fold
hoursPlayed: which is a very interesting place- albeit a bit bi-polar. You'll know what I mean when you get there. A lot of extra treasure is also added in both expansions. An interesting thing to note: there is no linearity in this game
voteText: that is to say you do not need to do the main quest first
helpfulPercent: or keep doing it after you start it. You can just as easily do every other quest in the game
votesHelpful: have a monstrous beast of a character and then embark on the main story. The possibilities are seemingly limitless
votesTotal: which is why I've played through this game multiple times with different characters- the "feel" of a Dark Elf heavy armor melee with destruction and marksman is fundamentally different than a High Elf deep magic caster with no armor but buffs/disrupts/nukes galore. Assassin-like characters are also great fun and very rewarding in this game thanks to a much better stealth system and huge damage bonuses in stealth. Pretty much every and any playstyle you can imagine is viable to play
votesFunny: and the ability to design your own classes is rewarding and in fact vital if you want maximum stat gains.\n\nMy parting advice: Read up on how to properly design your characters in a general sense to have maximum stat gains (+5 in 3 stats at every level up or close to it) ESPECIALLY FOR ENDURANCE. Get your endurance to 100 ASAP
commentsCount: the earlier you do it the higher your character's max health will be for the rest of the game. Conversely
column16: if you leave it low then as you level up the NPCs will outpace your health growth and become much more difficult to face.\n\n5/5- Highly recommend to fans and newcomers alike."

reviewText:
The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion was my first introduction to the Elder Scrolls franchise back when it first came out on the Xbox 360. I had more time on this game across the 3 Xbox 360's than almost anything else, and there's a reason for that: this game is fantastic.

I'm a guy that is most at home with RPGs, be it on PC or console and this is truly what I would consider a solid RPG. While it's true the graphics and many of the features are outdated, clunky, and annoying at times, many of these problems have been solved by the Steam and Nexus communities, and even some mods with features you didn't even know you wanted. I bought this with The Elder Scrolls Anthology and didn't play it off of Steam, hence the miniscule playtime, but I assure you, I've played this extensively.

The graphics are old, but they look better on PC than they ever did on console, and with the game's low load on your computer, even mid-tier computers can play it on high settings, and even include mods for more beautiful scenery. While there's not as much realism" and "grit" put into this game like Skyrim did

reviewText:
TESIV: Oblivion is a great game. Many TES fans refer to is as a classic, and I can see why.

Quests in this game are absolutley wonderful. The quests are very interesting, and you can get different outcomes depending on how you play, which makes the game very replayable. There is a lot of different ways to play this game, and you get to choose how you want to play.

The world is huge, and loading screens don't appear when you roam freely. The only time you will get a loading screen is if you enter a dwellin, so you can wonder all around Cyrodil without objections. The game world is enourmous, and with modifications, you can extend it even more. I doubt I will ever filly explore the map in Oblivion.

There is an enormous modding community. Even though there is not a Steam Workshop for Oblivion, installing mods is quick and somple. Modifications are still being developed, even while everyone else is playing Skyrim. Mods range from silly and funny to serious lore to really useful changes. The websites planetelderscrolls.ign.com and nexusmods.com/oblivion are very good resources that I use often.

reviewText: As a long-time Elder Scrolls fan, I must say that this game is truly a masterpiece. I remember when Morrowind came out, how fascinated I was by all of its intricacies. I couldn't believe that a game could feel so alive, that I could be so immersed in a plethora of cultures, ideologies, races and factions all while exploring a beautiful, detailed world and the history that shaped it into what you see it now. It was the stuff epic adventures are made out of.\n\nOblivion takes that core gameplay and expands quite a great deal upon it. The first thing you might notice is the graphical upgrade. Oblivion's graphics were so cutting edge at the time that they still hold up very nicely today. The main story arch is solid, with a well paced build up and a gripping finale. Sidequests, however, are where this game (much like its predecessor) truly shines. There are a lot of side quests, guild quests, artifacts to discover, spells/gear to craft. You will always have something to do, and I find it best to micromanage by assigning priority to your tasks rather than completing quests as you receive them. Thankfully, this game has a much better fast-travel system than Morrowind's, you can click on visited locations on your map to instantly travel there (does take in-game time, so vampires beware!) so back-tracking is manageable. This is a welcome upgrade, as Cyrodiil is a VERY big place. You will also find yourself trekking through the instanced" dungeons and planes of Oblivion quite often. Your adventures through these creature-laden locales will be aided by a very good quest compass
date: use it!\n\nThe expansions are quite good too
recommended: Shivering Isles adds Sheogorath's realm to the fold
hoursPlayed: which is a very interesting place- albeit a bit bi-polar. You'll know what I mean when you get there. A lot of extra treasure is also added in both expansions. An interesting thing to note: there is no linearity in this game
voteText: that is to say you do not need to do the main quest first

votesTotal: which is why I've played through this game multiple times with different characters- the "feel" of a Dark Elf heavy armor melee with destruction and marksman is fundamentally different than a High Elf deep magic caster with no armor but buffs/disrupts/nukes galore. Assassin-like characters are also great fun and very rewarding in this game thanks to a much better stealth system and huge damage bonuses in stealth. Pretty much every and any playstyle you can imagine is viable to play
votesFunny: and the ability to design your own classes is rewarding and in fact vital if you want maximum stat gains.\n\nMy parting advice: Read up on how to properly design your characters in a general sense to have maximum stat gains (+5 in 3 stats at every level up or close to it) ESPECIALLY FOR ENDURANCE. Get your endurance to 100 ASAP
commentsCount: the earlier you do it the higher your character's max health will be for the rest of the game. Conversely
column16: if you leave it low then as you level up the NPCs will outpace your health growth and become much more difficult to face.\n\n5/5- Highly recommend to fans and newcomers alike."

reviewText: I bought this game because it is the best in the franchise, I've bought the GOTY thrice, 360, PC(retail), and Steam, and played over a thousand hours on PC alone.  This is the most moddable game I've ever seen. More so than any GTA, hands down. I really bought it because back in the day when it came out, I didn't have a quater of the power in my PC as I do now. Now, oh NOW? I have maxed all settings, the largest Quarls texture packs, Kvatch Rebuilt, all the unofficial patches (over 1800 bugs Bethesda never fixed), all the official DLC (always have had that), all of the unique landscapes mods, Morrowblivion, Mart's Monster Mod, Ren's Beauty Pack, Signs retextured, Animated windows and chimneys, and that's before you consider that this game has overhaul mods that take everything to a new level. I'm talking new leveling systems, new spells, new monsters and giant monsters, new races, new weapons by the hundreds, new fauna and flora, better crafting and alchemy, more mounts, new quests and clans, new houses, new stores and merchants, enhanced UI for first and third person, attacking on horseback,  all on top of the original. Use Oblivion Mod Manager (OBMM) or Nexus Mod Manager (NMM) for best results. I have a modded version of this game on my PS3, and hand packing the mods into the game is worth it still. No Oblivion Script Extender support on PS3 though, so it really can only take mild texture enhancements like Ren's and simply scripted mods like better spells and additional merchants. Well if you've ever wanted a game that you would run more modded as The Sims here is your ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Every time I load this game up, and the beautiful Cryodill atmosphere renders and the music starts to play, I lose track of everything around me. My girlfriend ceases to matter, stopping to eat becomes a torturous experience, and yesterday I found out that Osama Bin Laden had been killed (not really but you get the point). This game and it's sequel, Skyrim, are a momentous step forward in humanity's quest to become couch-dwelling creatures.
The gameplay is nothing exactly new or innovative, just standard hack-and-slash-and-cast spells, but it is made tolerable and enjoyable when added with the overall package that is Oblivion.
The atmosphere is where this game shines. Set in a medieval European setting with valleys, forests, mountains, swamps, and gates to Hell, this game succeeds at pulling you in completely, with an epic soundtrack to complete it all.
The storyline is adequate and does give you a sense of purspo as you are playing.
All in all a very good game

reviewText:
(I usually play this game when i'm disconnected from steam, so i've been playing the game longer than what it says.)

This is my favorite Elder Scrolls game and before you ask, no, it was not my first.

Pros:

-Most of the quests are fun and unique
-Memorable quest/questlines
-Memorable characters
-Funny voice acting
-TONS of unique items
-Fun DLCs
-The envioment is bright and sunny conparted to Skyrim and Morrowind

Cons:

-Copy and paste dungeons
-The voice acting (yes I know I said it was funny, but some of it isn't very good by todays standards)
-Slow leveling
-The glitches

Putting the cons aside this is a great game with hours of content that you keep you busy for 100+ hours at the least. The main quest could of used a little more work but it isn't as bad as some people say it is. The DLCs were a big step up from the main quest. In knights of the Nine your on a holy crusade to fight against Umariil the Unfeathered, an ancient Ayleid elf who has come to try to enslave men once more! The Shivering Isles (If not my most favorite, one of my favorite parts of Oblivion) sends you the breathtaking realm of Sheogorath, the daedric prince of madness. The NPC dialogue will make you giggle and will put a smile on your face. (Seriously this DLC made me smile even when I didn't want to)
I would recommend this game to someone I don't even know! 9.9/10

4)Talk to everybody. Every single NPC. Because there is one guy who Bethesda was too lazy to put dialogue for so if you talk to him all you get is him standing there looking at you while the text I HAVE NO GREETING pops up.
5) Screenshot every glitch, because those are precious memories.
6) Bask in the wonderful voice of Patrick Stewart while you have the chance.
Great Game I give it 4 out of 5 Elder Scrolls.

reviewText:
This brilliant game from 2005 is an action packed rpg with a heroic storyline, you are the hero who is going to save the world from the daedric prince of destruction, Mehrunes Dagon. Venture across the land of Cyrodiil as you bypass lushious landscape and wonderous creatures. You will be amazed with the wonderful story telling. The epic soundtrack will help you feel immersed and ready to do some quests and fight creatures in dungeons or in the wilderness.

During or after the mainquest you can start the Knights of the Nines quest as you help the faction of the same name in their quest to find relics to defeat a sorcerer who are after the Knights of the nines.

Also at anytime you could start of the amazing Shivering Isles expansion pack that includes going the oblivion realm of Shivering Isles and visit the ruler Daedric Prince of Madness, Sheogorath. In this land is vast and range of creatures, colours and landscape. The whole island is split into two sections, Mania and Demetia. In this Expansion pack you shall help the ruler Sheogorath stop Jyggalag the daedric prince of order from turning Sheogoraths mad realm into his own.

You will surely have loads of fun playing this game, even though the people are potato faced the game is amazing and wonderful to play.

reviewText:
By Azura, by Azura, by Azura! It's GOTY Oblivion! I can't believe it's true! Right here, available on Steam!

Morrowind is considered the best of the Elder Scrolls series, but for me, Oblivion is what really takes the cake (which may or may not actually be Sheogorath in disguise.)
The graphics, while obviously dated, are vibrant and colorful, and still hold up relatively well. Sound design is fantastic as well, from the battle tracks, to the ambience, and everything in between.

The combat is a little lacking, and a lot of the time you won't even be sure if your attacks are hitting until the enemy goes flying off in to the sunset as a glitchy ragdoll, but it's fairly easy to overlook.
Which brings us to the story and quests, absolutely fantastic, most side quests can get pretty weird, like going into dreams worlds and literally entering paintings, and do a good job at bringing variety and laughs to the table. Most of which will come from the aforementioned Sheogorath, Daedric prince of madness, who I'm sure you'll be well aquanited with if you get the GOTY edition or the base game and Shivering Isles expansion.

Base Game/Vanilla
9/10

With Mods
20/10

reviewText:
Elder Scrolls IV is a HUGE RPG game. There is a storyline to work through, only if you want. This game is open-ended in terms of, if you don't want to complete the main story, don't. There are many side-quests, lands to explore, people to talk too, etc. The game starts you off, with creating your character who ends up in jail. You break out of jail, and the adventure begins however you want.

There are guilds to join, classes to have (magic, fighter, theif etc.) tons of customization options, and this game is a huge game. The audio and visuals are nice, day/night cycles, weather, the NPCs live their day to day life with advanced AI, the visual effects are top notch etc.

Even after all these years, you can still find a never ending quest in Elder Scrolls 4, and with the expansion pack and DLC content, this game is always having something new to do.

reviewText:
This was the game that started it for me and converted me overnight into an Elder Scrolls fanatic. Huge scale, especially for it's time, and you're simply thrown right into it the moment you finish the tutorial. The entirety of this gorgeous, meticulously-crafted world is open to you, with surprises and distractions at every turn. Walk in a straight line for not too far, and you'll find a door to a dungeon with a story, or a person with a request, or a concealed chest with a few goodies in it.

The stories the game tells are all great and well-written, not least of all the main quest; but I can almost guarantee the progression of the main quest will be only a mere fraction of the time you spend in this world. You will write your own stories in this game - Join the Thieves' Guild, become a cult assassin, travel the world as a mage apprentice, earn honor and glory in the Fighter's Guild, or hell, do all of that at once! If open-world and character-progression are your things, TES Oblivion is a quintessential game to have in your library.

Be sure to check out my reviews for Morrowind and Skyrim as well! (Spoilers: you'll probably want all three)

reviewText:
Ok. I've got over 200 hours on this game, and I'm pretty sure the time reset itself at some point. And I had it on the Xbox as well. I think that serves as an example of how much I like this game.

Honestly? The vanilla game is brilliant, but it isn't perfect. But you know why you get this game on the PC? Mods. If there's a problem, grab Wyre Bash, BOSS and go on the Nexus. You're sure to find something to fix it. Or maybe you just want more content, or a companion that is pretty much an artificial person? Mods can do that.

Of course, this isn't a review if I'm just gushing about it. I know most recommendations here on Steam are literally that, but I want to give you something to read. Because I love you.

The combat is lackluster. Really, it's just clicking a bunch. It takes much, much too long to bring down an oppenent, and too long for them to bring you down. There's of course mods for that - I don't use them anymore myself, but try Duke Patrick's combat mods.

The level scaling is... terrible. After you get to, say level 30, /all/ of the rats and wolves are replaced my minotaurs and bears. Bandits won't be wearing leather or fur, but high class glass. Ridiculous. One option to get around this is to choose major skills which will bring you to a specific level. For example, you might have 2 or 3 skills you actively use, and the rest you don't touch. This will keep you around level 20. The other option is, of course, mods. Frans will keep the scaling, but make it /sane/. OOO will remove it and make the world static, so one type of enemy will always be in the same dungeon. TIE is random, and adds a bunch of stealth related features. In the latter two, you will die a lot.

The game is poorly optimised. It will run fine without mods, but if you use them, espect some crashes. Don't expect to be able to load up on advanced textures and the like no matter how good your system is - it's only optimised for one core. There's plenty of INI tweaks which can help. It's recommended to Pyffi the meshes located in the game's BSAs. Don't ask me how to do this, I've forgotten and I just keep the BSAs I've made, but look it up. It sounds more intimidating than it is. There's also a few mods which help for stability, including unofficial patches, Streamline, Quiet Feet and several optimised meshes and textures. All in all, expect it to run worse than Skyrim, but it's not going to be nearly as bad as the PC port of Saints Row 2.

So, what's good about the game? Well, I can't say. I can't tell you why I love it so much. Maybe it's the freedom to do whatever you want and to explore? Maybe it's the almost humourous nature of the game, apparent whenever you see or hear an NPC? Maybe it's the world building, which isn't readily apparent to those who don't care to look, but read the books, or listening to the people, and you will know it.

I much prefer this over Morrowind, which has an interesting setting, and Skyrim, which has much better combat and perks. Oblivion has a kind of spirit to it, and with mods, you can change that spirit to whatever you choose. Everyone's game will be different.

The main shame, which I havn't seen fixed by any mods, is that Cyrodiil isn't the jungle setting described by previous games, and that the main quest is, unless you look into the lore, very black and white. I suppose a lot of people like clear morality, but not me. I find myself having to remind myself that deadra don't actually have a mortal's perception of morality at all.

But, perhaps I've dwelled on the downsides of this game too much? I hope that the amount of joy I get from playing it shows that the positives, whatever they might be, outweigh the negatives. ;)

reviewText:
This is a Western RPG essential! though you don't see my over 1000 hours played on xbox you must take my word for it. This game immersed me for hours! I would sit there playing it and then look at the clock and it would be four hors later. That being said it is a mssive time sink. So now I willtell you what you will like and what you will be looking for if you want to play a game like this.
Pros:
- Massive world
- Plenty of quests
- A very free and sometimes terrifying character creation system
- A huge Modding community, but does not support steam workshop. Quarl's Texture pack is a must! The nexus is great too!
- A brillant sense of adventure! I felt like exploring and continuing which is brillant!
- A great starter RPG. It's a great RPG to start with!
- The emperor is PATRICK STEWART! HE IS THE ONLY UNIQUE VOICE ACTOR AND HE DIES VERY QUICKLY BUT HE'S STILL PATRICK STEWART!
Now heres the part where I give you what is not so great about the game, because honestly no game is perfect no matter how much the rosey glasses of nostalgia say they are.
Cons
- Combat sucks. Theres no two was about it its really drab and boring and redundant it gets the job done though. Luckily there are mods that fix that! They're just a google search and a little research away!
- The cities can feel a bit small and under populated. The biggest city in the empire only has about 30 or so people. Though the issue is prominent in most Bethesda games it's still an issue that deserve acknowledgement.
- There are only 18 voice actors so it can be a bit imerssion breaking when you here people talking to each other with the same voice. Also the ambiant speech can be very redundant after while but tha might just be because I've played it for so much time.
- The system for making people like you is actually rather comical. Just a few presses of a button and you have new best friend!

Though there are certianly more little things wrong with this game such as how it is very buggy (Unnoffical oblivion patch fixes this issue and is easily installed on the nexus) It is still a game worth buying UNLESS ANY OF THOSE CONS ARE SO OFF PUTTING YOU DON'T WANT IT! However I have to say this is a brilliant game and is certianly worth buying! The DLC is awesome so if you get the chance and its on sale for oh say 5$ or 7.50$ it is an easy insta-buy. You will get your money's worth I promise, or it will sit in your back log because ya know steam. So all and all a good purchase!

reviewText:
Oblivion and Skyrim (plus all add-ons) are the best RPG's i have ever played! They are so vast that you can spend 100 hours on one character and if you start a new character you can have a completely different game/experience! The thing i love about these games are the fact it is not linear at all (as i find with a lot of RPG's), so you can basically do what you want when you want and at what pace you want.

Also, the graphics for Oblivion and in particular Skyrim are fantastic as alot of RPG's sacrifice graphics for gameplay/storyline etc. however both these titles have the best of both!

The only minor fault with this game (and this is me just being objective) is that when you get past a certain point/level with your character it can be a little bit to easy even when set to high difficulty taking some of the challange away.

If you like the RPG genre then you will love The Elder Scrolls: Oblivion & Skyrim and i would highly recomend this to anyone!

I rate both these 9/10 (one of the best games i have EVER played)

reviewText:
Although I must admit Bethesda never made it up to their ladder since Morrowind, I cannot deny my endless weeks and years of holidays spend on this (smaller than morrowind but still) pretty gem.

Oblivion is just like the rest of the Elder Scrolls games a game that relies on the core mechanics and principles of an RPG Sandbox. Which means easy to use and familiar gameplay, a big open world to mess around in and lots of magic and clashing swords.

The things I like about Bethesda's Elder Scrolls is that each game has his own look and feel. You want to be inside that game, you want to be able to see and do even more than you already can. Oblivion also succeeded in this, making this game a true childhood piece of awesomeness.

I still like it now I look at it from a different perspecive though, simply because of the (still familiar) easy to understand basics and smoothness of the gameplay itself. It's not hard, nor is it too easy. All the way in completing the quests you'll find easier and more challenging creatures. It's just so easy to pick up from where you left!
And that is one thing that is very important. The game has some bugs and glitches, and the leveling system isn't that ideal, but it still doesn't fail to entertain even now I'm grown up and reaching for the Game Industry myself.

The expansions and add-ons are sometimes a little unnecessary, though fun when you've completed the main quests.

Oh, and the main reason for it being less awesome as Morrowind is simply because morrowind had everything. No really; it had EVERYTHING!

Again, never get's boring, easy to lose yourself in, great setting, 8/10.

reviewText:
Excellent game, worth buying for the mods if not for the base game itself. I would look at things that rebalance it (as well as the amazing total conversion mod Nehrim). Any problems that anyone has with the game can literally be fixed by modders and most likely are. I have spent dozens of hours in this game (had the boxed editions with mods on my old computer, but they got trashed along with it).

As far as storytelling goes, the story is quite compelling as compared to Skyrim. The guild quests in this game are fantastic, with the Dark Brotherhood and the Thieves Guild coming to mind as having some of the coolest moments in the game. It feels epic without taking away freedom from the player character and I can guarantee that you will be reloading saves or creating new characters to try out all kinds of different approaches.

Glitches do happen, as expected of a Bethesda game, but most of the time they do not take away from the experience. Otherwise a lot of them are fixed by player patches or have documented workarounds.

Graphics are great for the time it was released, though they can be optimised quite a bit by installing a few patches to improve framerate. There are also a ton of high resolution mods that make the game pretty enough that you can just walk around marvelling at the world around you. People have added entire worldspaces into the game and redesigned cities, as well as made them accessible from the outside instead of going through the doors.

The playstyle of the game is pretty decent, though combat does not feel as naunced as a title like Mount & Blade. But if you're looking at this, you're probably buying it on PC so go download some of the amazing combat mods out there.

Overall, if you're looking for a game that has aged remarkably well and has an amazing series of mods that ensure that you will probably never be done playing it, Oblivion is for you. Skyrim may have a much more updated engine but this old game still shines.

reviewText:
This game is simply fantastic. The whole world is very filled up, to the point where you an just spend hours going dungeon to dungeon getting new loot. The towns all have enough variation to make them all feel different from each other and have their own feel. The combat has a pretty strategic feel to it; the game gives you different effects which each melee power attack as you progress, allowing for some pretty engaging fights. Unfortunately, the ranged combat types don't have quite as much detail as the melee, but they make up for this in sheer effectiveness. The magic is very fun to use, as you can create your own spells later in the game, which give you some advantages in both combat and passive situations. But wait, there's more!

The absolute BEST part of this game is the modding community. It's really, REALLY big. You can change how your combat works, get armor retextures, even change the game to have an XP system. You won't really run out of stuff to do; quest mods are there too (Some of them are pretty fantastic, I recommend Knights of the Nine: Revelation). All in all, the game is fantastic, and you should pick it up if you don't already have it.

reviewText: No, I mean. No. A game literally can not be this damn good. There's a bias in my opinion of course, having played this game before I played Morrowind and Skyrim, but all things considered, Oblivion is the highlight of the series. With Morrowind you had great variation in the environment and a truly wonderful game. And then came Oblivion, offering many, many, many hours of gameplay [I have 2500+ on PS3] and an incredible replay value. A game is all about how it makes you feel. Oblivion, with it's bright and vivid colours, compelling story, and amazing design makes you feel like you're in the game. I don't want to sound completely biased, so I want to say some negative things about it, which is hard for me. There are [it being a Bethesda game, after all] a fair share of its bugs and glitches. A few quests in the game were scrapped halfway through, and hearing people reference these quests which can't be completed, initaded, or even alluded to more than once are bothersome. The design of caves, forts, and dungeons can get repetitve. Many people complain about the NPC's faces, which, in the reality of things, aren't bad. Some are absolutely revolting [Bruma guards, specifically. And this one guard in Anvil], but the majority are well done. The soundtrack is the best I've ever heard. The music is cheerful, and fits the environment perfectly. [Jeremy Soule has a talent for that, look at KotOR]. The variation in the wilderness and in the cities is delightful. Each city has its own style of architecture, influenced by various cultures from The Elder Scrolls series. Easily my favorite game of all time, no matter what genre you're interested in, give it a try. Put away any preconceived notions of the game's quality based on graphics [which aren't even that bad, especially for 2006] and experience that which is Oblivion.

reviewText: The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a great game, and one of my favorite open world games ever. This is a game that every RPG fan should try out. I admit, Skyrim might have more content, better controls and a few other things, but Oblivion have an amazing Fantasy feel to it. But not only that, it also have (in my opinion) better quests. The guilds in Oblivion (Dark Brotherhood, Mages Guild, Fighters Guild and so on) are in my opinion much better then the Guilds in Skyrim.\n\nAnyway, Oblivion is a great game, and i would recommend it to anyone who is a big Fantasy fan, or people who like big open worlds. It might be hard to immerse yourself into it now, seeing as it is an older game, but once you get into it, you are not going to regret playing it.

reviewText: Probably one of the best games I've ever played, kept me entertained for a long time on console, and finally got it on pc to give it a go here. Wonderful, personally find it better than Skyrim, because to me, Skyrim you are paying for graphics, Oblivion you are paying for a game. Oblivion can be very easily modded, but seeming that it doesn't have a steam workshop, it makes the process generally longer, but, as Gaben had once said ; ' Worth the Wait. ' Oblivion will more than likely keep you occupied for easily 200-300 hours, and is very easily replayable, because of the different races, and some perks that some races get. The map of Oblivion is easy to read, when Skyrim's map was rather awkward to read, because of the stupid angle. Oblivion's storyline is rather a small portion of the game, when there is guilds, e.g Fighters Guild, Thieves guild. Some of the quests in Oblivion can be quite lengthy, and some even require you to be a certain level to complete/start a quest. The combat system of Oblivion is rather simple, where Skyrim you couldn't use a spell with a sword and shield for example, where as in Oblivion, you can use a unlocking spell, and you can just rush into a building, loot, and complete a mission for a guild.\n\nI highly reccommend Oblivion, and would definately choose it over Skyrim.
